April 24, 1936.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Funds are provided, in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to carry out certain repairs at the Indian Residential School at Portage la Prairie, Manitoba. Among other improvements required, it is necessary to overhaul the hot water heating system for the laundry, baths, etc., at an estimated cost of $275.00. Mr. Agent Waite, Portage la Prairie, has forwarded a quotation obtained by the Principal of the School from J. W. Rames, Plumber and Fitter, Portage la Prairie, for supplying any materials required and the labour, installing same. Mr. Waite states that he considers the work in the repairing and alterations to the hot water heating system to be very necessary and urgent.

I should be pleased to be advised if it would be satisfactory to have Mr. Rames do the work or to receive the names of other plumbers in the city of Portage la Prairie, who should be asked to estimate on the work. At the present time, the school is without hot water for laundry and bathing purposes.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Mr. J. D. Sutherland,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

May 1st, 1936.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Re: Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School

I have a copy of a letter written April 20th to the Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs by Mr. Jones, the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Residential School.

I hope that until full investigation of the situation has been made the Department will go slowly in acceding to some of Mr. Jones' suggestions. One thing which could be done immediately would be to fit the kitchen range with coils and a good-sized tank, adequate to supply hot water for the kitchen. It seems rather strange that he did not attend to an absolute essential like that before some of the other major changes which he has made since he took over the School.

I wonder why we should not put the steam boiler in the laundry into action rather than move it to the basement and use it as a hot water heater. I cannot remember just at the moment where the laundry is located in the Portage School, but the new system which has been installed at Mameey works so admirably that I am wondering why we could not use this to provide hot water - not only for the laundry - but for the rest of the building. Meanwhile, Mr. Jones must have a tank, with a small jacket heater underneath it. Supplying him with a jacket heater as a temporary measure, as was done at Norway House, while we work out the whole problem would seem to be the logical thing to do. I would like to know what the Department, who have a complete plan of the School in their possession, are considering.

Yours very sincerely,

KJB.MLT

[Signature]

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, May 4th, 1936.

Referring to your memorandum of the 24th ultimo, file 127-1-5, in reference to certain work being done at the Indian Residential School at Portage la Prairie, the Minister suggests that you should give this work to Mr. Gordon McKay, Portage la Prairie, that is providing the price he quotes is satisfactory. He is well qualified to do the work.

U.W. Jackson,
Private Secretary.
Ottawa, May 6, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department has received a communication from Mr. Agent Waite, with letter attached from the Principal of the Portage La Prairie Indian Residential School, requesting that the changes, as mentioned in the letters, be made to the hot water heating facilities for kitchen use and for laundry and other purposes at the school.

For your information, I may say that the following items were provided in our Estimates for this school for the current fiscal year:

Repairs to balcony - $800.
Repairs to cow barn and implement shed - $475.
Paint, varnish, etc., for interior, school building, decorating - $100.

I would request that, at your early convenience, you will visit the above named school and enquire carefully into the requests of the Principal, regarding the alterations and improvements in the heating system, also the repairs required to the balcony, cow barn and implement shed.

May I say, also, for your private information, that a communication has been received from the authorities of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, regarding the request of the Principal, from which the following quotations are taken:

"I hope that, until full investigation of the situation has been made, the Department will go slowly in acceding to some of Mr. Jones' suggestions. One thing which could be done immediately would be to fit the kitchen range with coils and a good-sized tank, adequate to supply hot water for the kitchen. It seems rather strange that he did not attend to an absolute essential like that before some of the other major changes he has made since he took over the school.

"I wonder why we should not put the steam boiler in the laundry into action rather than move it to the basement and use it as a hot water heater. Meanwhile, Mr. Jones must have a tank, with a small jacket heater underneath it. Supplying him with a jacket heater as an emergency measure, as was done at Norway House, while we work out the whole problem would seem to be the logical thing to do."

The Minister has directed that, should any plumbing be undertaken, this work should be given to Mr. Gordon McKay,

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

Reverend Sir:

Replying to your letter of the first instant, addressed to Mr. Sutherland, of this Department, relative to a communication you received from the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, with reference to the providing of hot water heating facilities for kitchen use and for laundry and other purposes, I have to say that Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, is being instructed to visit the school and make careful enquiry. Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of Department Letter 127-1-5 dated May 6th, together with telegram of same date. This work is now under way.

However, it was found that the upright boiler needed a complete new set of flues, consequently this increased the cost. Mr. McKay, Mr. Weite, and myself went carefully into the situation at the Portage la Prairie School and we are convinced that, with the changes anticipated, the school will be furnished with abundance of hot water, at the lowest possible cost. The material and labour will cost approximately $350. I informed Mr. Jones, Principal of the school, that this amount would be deducted from the $475 allowed for repairs to the cow barn and implement shed.

I might just add that in my opinion the repairs requested are not urgently needed, other than that six extra stanchions be provided and properly installed to accommodate more cattle. Mr. Jones is anxious to have the city water connected with the stables. However, this is not necessary as he at present has a good well inside the barn.

As soon as the work is completed, the vouchers will be forwarded to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir:

I wish to refer to Department Letter 127-1-5 dated May 6th, and to say that the repairs required for the balcony at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School should be carried out this year. It is in a dilapidated condition and needs to be raised and made level. The floors need renewing and the front should be fitted with windows and screens. This balcony is on the cold side of the building and, when properly repaired, will no doubt reduce considerably the cost of heating.

Mr. Jones, the Principal, is a first class carpenter and I have no doubt that the full amount of $800 will be required to make the necessary repairs. He states he is willing to supervise the work, but is of the opinion that a first class carpenter should be hired as he himself has other duties to attend to and could not be present all the time.

Mr. Jones is anxious to start the work at once and I would request that the necessary authority be granted.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

It is intended to carry out the following work, for which funds are provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School (Electoral District of Portage la Prairie), Man.:-

Repairs to balcony - $500.

Supplying paint, varnish, etc., for interior decorating - $100.

Mr. Inspector Hamilton states that the balcony at this school is in a dilapidated condition and needs to be raised and made level, that the floors require renewing and the front fitted with windows and screens. This balcony is on the cold side of the building, and, when repaired, the cost of heating would be considerably reduced.

The Principal is a first-class carpenter and he states he is willing to supervise the work but requests the services of a carpenter to assist him.

I would request your authority to incur an expenditure of $500 in repairing the balcony and purchasing paint, to the amount of $100, and I shall be pleased to receive the name of a competent carpenter to assist the Principal in carrying out the repairs.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir:

Attached is a rough sketch of the septic tank and outlet in connection with the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

The syphon should be renewed at once. The pipe line leading from the septic tank to the lake shore should be uncovered; one branch is useless and the indications are that the pipe on the other branch is liable to give way at any time. If the pipe needs to be renewed, I would recommend that it be extended from the septic tank straight to the lake shore, as indicated on the enclosed sketch.

This work will probably cost $150. to $200. and should be carried out as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, May 29, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your 208-11A U of the 21st instant, with sketch showing the proposed new outlet from the septic tank at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School and stating the work required and the probable cost.

In connection with the septic tank, the Department has had correspondence with the Department of Health and Public Welfare, Manitoba, also a report dated March 11th, last, from Mr. D. B. Gow, District Engineer, Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau, regarding the discharge from the tank into Crescent Lake. He reported that, after discussing the situation with the Chief Sanitary Inspector, Department of Health and Public Welfare of the Province, the attitude of the Inspector was that the sewage disposal plant met the requirements of the Manitoba Department of Health and that there was little ground for the complaint made by the town of Portage la Prairie.

It is hoped, if the new outlet is made, as suggested by you, that there would be no objection from the Health authorities or the town of Portage la Prairie in having the sewage from the tank continue to enter the lake. However, before the Department is prepared to authorize any expenditure in renewing the pipeline with a new outlet, it is considered advisable that you refer the matter to Mr. Gow and obtain his report and also his opinion concerning what should be done in placing the sewage disposal system at the school in good condition, with an estimate of the cost.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir:

I have your Nos. 208-11A U. of the 19th ultimo, regarding the repairs required to the upright boiler and improvements in the hot water heating system, as well as the repairs required to the balcony at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

Regarding the hot water heating system, it is noted that a complete new set of flues is required, that you and the Principal have gone carefully into the situation and that the changes planned will furnish the school with an abundance of hot water. It is noted, further, that the cost of the material and labour will be approximately $350. - this amount to be deducted from the $475 provided for repairs to the cow barn and implement shed. I would request, when this work is completed, that you forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the materials, and accounts, in triplicate, for the labour. The latter should show the number of days or hours employed and the rate paid.

It is noted that the repairs to the cow barn are not urgently required, other than six extra stanchions, properly installed, to accommodate more cattle. You may arrange for the purchase and installation of six stanchions.

The Department is not prepared to consider having the city water connected with the stables. There is a well inside the barn and this should serve the purpose.

With reference to the repairs required to the

- balcony,

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.
balcony and also the purchase of paint, varnish, etc., for interior decorating of school building, I would inform you that the minister approves the expenditure of approximately $200 for material and labour in repairing the balcony and an expenditure not exceeding $100 in the purchase of the paint and varnish. Ottawa, September 9, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your 208-11A U., of the 4th instant, enclosing copy of a report from the Acting District Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power and Hydroelectric Bureau, Winnipeg, which deals with the condition of the septic tank at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

It is noted the Engineer is of opinion, if temporary repairs are made at the present time, that the present sewage disposal system will carry the school through the coming winter. In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure, not exceeding $125.00, in carrying out the temporary work suggested by the Engineer. All costs should be kept to the lowest possible point. When the work is completed, itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of any materials and labour, should be forwarded. Regarding any extra labour that it may be necessary to employ, over and above what can be performed by the school staff, full particulars should be stated on the vouchers, giving number of days or hours employed and rate paid.

August 31, 1936.

Sir:

As requested by you I visited the Portage la Prairie Indian School in connection with complaints from the school management as regards the sewage disposal system. The Principal was absent upon the occasion of my first visit but at a later date I was able to contact him.

As you are aware, the sewage disposal layout at this school is quite old; there are no drawings showing the installation and it appears impossible to obtain reliable data regarding what the system really consists of. The School Management, during the winter of 1935-36, were obliged, on account of the backing up of sewage into the school, to excavate down to the pipes leading both into and from the septic tank, clean out the same and upon numerous occasions had to clean out the septic tank.

From our own observations and those of the present Principal of the school, it would appear that the sewage situation at the Institution is as follows:

Roof drainage does not pass through the septic tank and is not drained into Crescent Lake. Laundry and kitchen drainage flows with the sewage into the septic tank in one outlet from the school. There are two manholes giving access to this discharge line between school and septic tank but there is no screen in front of the septic tank. The tank itself of concrete is divided into two parts with a 6" opening between the two. Information is not available as to the size of the tank or as to what is in the syphon portion of the chamber. A manhole gives access to the settling part of the tank but there is no means of access to the syphon chamber. I do not know whether or not a syphon was ever installed in the syphon chamber but in any case there is now none in operation. I understand there are no baffles in the settling chamber and that in reality the whole tank is one chamber insofar as action is concerned. The syphon chamber has never been cleaned out, there being no means of access - it is probably filled with solid matter, even to the extent of blocking the entrance and exit to the chamber. There are two outlets from the syphon chamber, one of which is completely blocked with solids. The other outlet had a broken pipe joining the tank and it was blocking at this outlet that created much trouble last winter. Apparently these two outlets unite before being discharged above the water line into Crescent Lake. Upon the occasion of my last visit August 20th, to the school, there was a strong disagreeable odor from the discharge extending even to the entrance to the school.

The troubles experienced last winter will probably again occur this coming winter unless remedial measures are undertaken. The trouble probably lies in the blocking of the syphon chamber and the two outlets. Cleaning out of the syphon chamber, opening up the blocked

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
outlet and replacing broken pipe in the other outlet will probably eliminate trouble during the coming winter. To gain access to the siphon chamber it may be necessary to break down the wall between the two parts of the tank. This wall serves no useful purpose under present conditions anyway.

I would suggest, as a temporary measure, that the siphon chamber be cleaned out and that the two outlets be opened up near the tank and be put in working condition. However, the sewage disposal system at this school is obsolete and in view of the frequent complaints from Portage la Prairie residents, it is advisable to modernize the system next summer holidays. I would suggest that the laundry and kitchen wastes be segregated in the building and be drained directly past the septic tank, that a new and enlarged septic tank be constructed with settling basin, siphon chamber and siphon. I would also suggest the lowering of the outlet drain from septic tank to lake so that the outlet is at or below the water level.

It will probably cost $100.00 to $125.00 to carry out the temporary work suggested now and $1,650.00 to modernize the disposal system next year.

Yours truly,

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.
In reply to Department Letter 127-1-5 dated May 29th, I now enclose copy of a report received from Mr. Gow of the Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau, which deals with the condition of the septic tank at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

It will be noted that Mr. Gow is of the opinion that temporary repairs can be made which will carry the school through the coming winter. The cost, I am sure, can be kept within Mr. Gow's estimate.

I think provision should be made in the 1937-38 Estimates to cover the cost of a new disposal system. Mr. Gow sets this figure at approximately $1650.

I would like to be advised at once if the necessary repairs may be proceeded with.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General:-

I have Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the 13th instant, regarding the amount authorized for interior painting at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

In this connection I would say that funds to carry out the following work are provided in the Estimates for Indian Education for the current Fiscal year:-

Repairs to balcony - - - - $800.
Supplying paint, varnish, etc., for interior decorating - - 100.

Accounts have been received to the amount of $1,255, covering the cost of the repairs to the balcony. The local Agent states the extra cost, above the estimate, was due to more lumber being required and also to the installing of flashing on the valleys and leads on the balconies and the painting that was carried out after the work was completed.

In view of the additional cost of the balconies, the Agent would not approve of the expenditure of $100 being incurred by the Principal in the purchase of paint for interior decoration. We can provide funds, to the amount of $100, in the purchase of paint and are informing the local Indian Agent accordingly. He is being instructed to arrange for the purchase of paint, varnish, etc., to that amount, for the purpose of interior decorating.

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Mackenzie,

With reference to the attached letter from Mr. Harry Leader, M. P., forwarding a communication from Stanley Bugg, in which he makes complaint regarding the rate of wages paid him for carpenter work in connection with the repairs carried out to the balcony at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School during July and August, last, I have to report as follows:

The Minister directed that the carpenter work be placed in charge of W. L. Moffatt, Portage la Prairie, and Mr. Inspector Hamilton was informed accordingly. Accounts were submitted for payment to two carpenters employed on the job - W. L. Moffatt and Jack Elwood - and a voucher in payment to Stanley Bugg, as "Labourer". The two former were paid at the rate of 65¢ per hour, and Stanley Bugg, at 35¢ per hour.

From the information contained on the voucher, it would appear that Stanley Bugg was not engaged as a carpenter and performed the work of a labourer only. However, we are writing Mr. Agent Waite for an explanation as to the wages paid Stanley Bugg and requesting, if he considers Bugg has a legitimate claim, that he forward a voucher for the amount.

WINNIPEG, MAN., January 11th, 1937.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of December 21st, and to say that I had occasion to be in Portage la Prairie on January 6th, on which date I inspected the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

When a wind is blowing, it is indeed very difficult to heat the building. However, this is not altogether the fault of the furnace as the building is old and out in the open where there is no protection.

The boiler is put out by the Schwab Heating Company, but, although old, appears to be in good condition. It no doubt consumes more fuel than the more modern type of boiler. Last year a blower attachment was supplied and this makes it possible to obtain a very hot fire.

The fire box is large and I am sure, when I examined the furnace, there were at least 200 lbs. of coal on the fire and this was a blazing mass such as one might find when a forge is being operated.

In spite of this fire, the dormitories on the north and west side of the building were extremely cold. It would be impossible for one to sit down and spend any time in the dormitory. I am sure the children find it very cold in the morning when they get up to dress. The windows are supplied.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
are supplied with outside sash, but there is still a lot of cold air admitted. It would improve the condition to fit another storm sash on the inside. However, as the windows are quite large and numerous, this would entail considerable expense.

The ceiling of the dormitories consist of common boards nailed to the joists and covered with tin. The ceiling must be 18 ft. high at least and I am sure a lot of the heat escapes in this way. There is a long hall running through the centre of the building and the ceiling of this hall, together with the ceiling over all the closets, is 4 ft. lower than the ceiling of the dormitories. The wall of the dormitories along this 4 ft. space is lath and plaster and there is no doubt what heat there is goes to the top of the room and gets out through this thin coat of plaster. These walls should be sided and insulated. I am also of the opinion that it would pay to insulate the ceiling of the dormitories. The work could easily be carried out by the Principal and the shavings and lime necessary would not run into a large amount of money. The electric wiring is all enclosed in pipe, so there would be no danger of a fire.

Up to the present time they have burned 100 tons of coal, costing $455, and Mr. Jones, the Principal, states it will cost at least another $700. Last year the total cost for fuel was $1500. The reduction this year we figure is partly due to the milder weather this fall and to the improvement made when the verandahs were enclosed on the west side of the school. I have no doubt the cost of heating could be considerably reduced if the above improvements were carried out and I feel this should be done, even though a new furnace were being installed.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

Indian Res. School R.H.P.

Early in this winter I wrote you as to the defects in the heating of this building. I suggested that the doors and windows were in much need of the attention of an experienced general Carpenter and that the ceiling in particular should be insulated.

An Inspector presumably from the Dept. of Public Works visited the building in January of this year. I did not see him of course as his visit was made in the day time. I understand he suggested that the ceiling should be insulated. Subsequently I am informed the Superintendent of the School was asked to measure the area of the ceiling which I presume was done.
I think I mentioned before that the steam pipe arrangement is defective in so much as that the live steam supplies the sheltered part of the building and the exposed part yet what is left over after heating the sheltered portions that on a cold night to get heat to the part that needs it involves overheating the sheltered.

The system might be named a modified single-return. I would suggest that it should be still further modified.

My suggestion have been with a view to securing for the children some degree of comfort and a reduction of the cost of that comfort.

What I have already put forward if carried out will do so in cold weather. There is the circumstance of the mild weather to be taken care of. To meet this I make this suggestion which will also to some degree take care of this overheating of the sheltered part.

Run a feed pipe from the capota or steam chest to the return pipe where it descends to the rear bottom of the boiler.
The steam pipe on leaving the Cepola goes straight into the kitchen; there it branches out past joints north, the other going south. As it proceeds, it becomes a water pipe returning the condensed steam to the boiler. Up to the point where the two pipes descend to the bottom of the boiler they are well above the top of the boiler.

I propose that these two pipes should be also steam pipes, as well as water pipes. A new feed from the Cepola to each of these pipes just before they bend to descend will have the effect of putting two steam where none yet now is, to the radiators in the two hospital wards and the nurses' rooms. They will also have the effect of giving steam to the N.W. and S.W. dormitories without the extra pressure that overheats the East side of the building.

In mild weather it will enable the heating to be done as a "Vapor" installation at greatly reduced cost.

The cost to make this slight alteration or rather addition to the piping should not be great and will be saved in the future winter fuel bill.

Yours truly,

Wm. E. Harris
Ottawa, March 13th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

I am forwarding to you an outline of our recent conversation re-Repairs, Improvements & Equipment for this school.

First. Consideration of increasing grant from 90 to 100 pupils this year. During the past two years I have been caring for additional pupils above the grant earning pupils. At present I have 54 boys & 46 girls in residence and 6 others wanting to come in. I have already discharged 12 this quarter. There are many more children on the four reserves that ought to be in this or some other school. To reduce our pupilage by sending ten of these children home would be a great injustice to them.

Second. The heating system is very unsatisfactory. We do not get the heat and comfort from the amount of fuel used. The engineer who examined the plant at the request of the Department submitted an estimate which was forwarded to the Department. The boiler inspector was here on August 10th and reported "Renew Front Manhole front, Repair front and sides brickwork which is in very bad shape."

Third. Repairs to leaking roof. New valley flashings required. If this is not done soon the valley rafters will rot and let down the roof.

Fourth. Carpenter and repair shop required at once in order to begin Manual Instruction classes, and also to provide facilities for repairing and overhauling machinery during the winter months. The practical instruction in all forms of mechanics for these boys is the best type of education.

Fifth. Insulating of ceiling in school and grouting of all window frames. Estimated cost for insulation $350.00 Grouting $74.00

Sixth. Water bowls and connections for barn. Estimated cost $134.35
Seven. Electric refrigeration. Estimate already sent in to the Department.

Eight. New Septic Tank and connecting sewer. I am sure there will be objections from the City and Municipal authorities to the present state of the disposal entering Crescent Lake.

Nine. Replacement of team which died from the disease (Encephalitis) which is destroying so many horses in Manitoba. Estimated cost for team $350.00. May I remind the Department that I have had to purchase 6 head of horses and 21 Jersey Cows during the past two years and I cannot spend any more of my grant in replacing stock.

I have outlined our needs in the order of their urgency and I trust you will give them your best and early consideration.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

I am enclosing herewith a list of repairs submitted to the Department for consideration by the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

I may state that Mr. Jones discussed these items with me, personally, when he visited Ottawa a few weeks ago. Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 127-1-5 dated September 15th, I will deal with each request as listed -

1. - The heating system is old but Mr. Jones' estimate of $75.00 to $100.00 will do the necessary repair work. This is urgently needed.

2. - New valley flashings required and the work should be carried out this fall. Will probably cost $75.00 to $100.00.

3. - Already have a building to meet this need. Attached is a small sketch showing the building and location.

4. - This building is really very cold, especially the dormitories and if at all possible, I would recommend the insulation. Cost approximately $350.00.

5. - Well and pump in the barn - equipment not urgent.

6. - Refrigeration should be estimated for. Only material and electrical equipment needed as Mr. Jones can build the box.

7. - No serious complaints from anyone. Mr. Jones appears most concerned. Should be in the estimates for next year. It will cost at least $1500.00.

8. - Mr. Jones now wants his gas engine replaced instead of the team. The present engine is 20 years old and would bring about $100.00. A new engine will cost $1100.00. A good team can be purchased now for $275.00 but will higher in the spring.

The question of more land is one for the Department to decide. The land desired by the principal lies across the lake from the school. It will likely be expensive and when purchased Mr. Jones will immediately want money to build a bridge across; probably three to five hundred dollars. If a fifty acre block adjoining the school farm could be purchased I would recommend it, providing the price is fair but beyond this I am not prepared to go.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Mr. Jones is firmly of the opinion, because he has one hundred pupils in residence, he should receive a grant for one hundred. His allowance is $90. I pointed out that no principal should take it upon himself to enroll more children than his allotted number. The dormitories have perhaps sufficient cubic feet of air space but this is ruined by the extremely high ceiling - 15 ft. The floor space of two dormitories is 756 sq. feet each and for the other two 650 sq. feet each. It is also impossible to walk between the beds except sideways. The building is poorly constructed and in my opinion, it would be impossible to control a fire if one occurred. Overcrowding would increase the risk and I am not prepared to make the recommendation.

As an alternative, and for your consideration, I present the following - a new day school on the Long Plain Reserve, costing perhaps $2000.00 - very little more than one year's grant for ten pupils. If this was carried out there would be no waiting list for the Portage school and no need for more farm land. The Indians of Long Plain are doing very well and many would welcome having their children come attending a good day school.

I believe a decision must soon be made either to increase the outlay and pupils at Portage or build day schools. A day school at Long Plain would perhaps help to decide the problem.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

Mr. H. Laird, Esq.,

Dear Mr. Laird:

Your letter arrived in this morning's mail and I was interested in reading your comments on the heating plant at the Indian school. We discussed this quite fully in your house recently and so I am pretty well conversant with the ideas which you present. Just as soon as I have an opportunity I will discuss this matter with Mr. Hoey and see if he is at all interested.

I was going to say that if your suggestion had the support of Mr. Jones, Superintendent, it would have additional support. I presume, however, he is fully in accord with your suggestion.

Mrs. Leader and I are quite established in our little apartment where she does her own housekeeping. We are quite comfortable in spite of the weather which is very changeable, alternating rain with snow and hard frost. The streets are very slippery, but we manage to paddle around some way.

With kind regards to you and yours,

I remain-

Yours sincerely,

Harry Leader, M.P.
Harry Leader by Int.
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

Enclosed in my letter today about the Indian School.

I have not succeeded in securing the name of the inspector who was first sent to inspect the school and suggested insulation—but I am of the impression it was Thomson.

I know it is structurally feasible to make the slight change I suggest—I experimented at my own expense, and my finding was verified by Gordon McKay at the time of the second inspection—which was the first time the heating plant was really looked at—

So far as I know the repairs & the windows were never considered possibly because of the very mild weather prevailing at the times of the inspection.

I hope, for the sake of these poor kids you can prevail on the authorities to put their feet in the air and do things which is right by them unfortunate.

I got the first of the newspapers today—thanks.

Your very truly,

Dear Sir,

Indian School

A year ago I wrote Mr. Hoey concerning the condition of the Indian School here and of the advanced almost cruel imposition on the helpless Indian children (about 100 of them) who as inmates are compelled to sleep in the dormitories provided.

I pointed out that the run down condition of the windows permitted the wind to blow across the rooms which is no joking matter when the temperature is down below zero and often 30° to 40° below as it was during the past two winters of this winter so far it has been mild with little wind.

The building is steam heated (low pressure). The heating plant as constructed is inadequate and on cold nights the steam rarely reaches the dormitories in the N.W., S.W. corners, and one might say never reaches the Hospital ward.

The ventilation is what might be termed a modified "single return" plant etc. It is doubtless
return" as to the main steam pipe and "single return" as to two series to the individual radiators.

As a result of my representations an inspector was sent from Winnipeg. He arrived for his "inspection" when the weather was fine and mild almost a thaw. I understand the main total of his inspection was a suggestion that the ceiling of the upper floor might be insulated.

Nothing about the windows or the heating plant. No conditions of this inspection would not, could no show up the defects, so no report.

I again wrote Mr. Hoey—this resulted in a more thorough inspection, but it was made under fine spring weather conditions—a further inspection was made and I understand a report was made that called for a large capital expenditure.

The net result of these 3 inspections is that the only repairs made in 1987 was replacement of damage done to the south range.
Apart from the welfare of the children, the condition of the building and heating plant is such that at least a third of the cost might be that some nights half of the cost of heating is money thrown away—some $500.

I suggested to Mr. Hoey that a carpenter should be hired to put the windows and storm windows into weatherproof condition—that would take I believe 6 weeks for a good journeyman carpenter.

The heating plant should be modified by connecting two boilers with the return end of the main steam pipe. This would require two 4 inch pipes, the top of the boiler to the two return pipes. It is mechanically feasible and a steam fitter and helper should do a complete job in three days.

The effect would be that the rooms now receiving no heat would have live steam by a complete single return system. The system would then be half the modified single return and half single return. The saving in cost of heating would pay for the repairs to the windows and the alteration to the heating plant. No capital expenditures.
There is no doubt that ventilation of the upper ceiling would effect further savings but the first thing in the repairs to the windows, second getting the heating plant into an effective condition. Third the ventilati

As you know I was on the staff for the winters of 1935-6 and 1936-7. On cold nights the nurse had to have coal oil stoves in the hospital rooms to get the heat up to 50°. She often had to tie on the bed with bed clothing over her to keep warm.

As a last word I would say the neglect of the Indian School at Portage la Prairie is a disgrace to Canada and a waste of public funds.

Yours very truly,

Wm. E. Lewis
Ottawa,

July 18th 1938

Dear Mr Waite,

Gibb, McCaig & Elwood are supplying the material for Implement-sheds, Granary, Workshop, Tremco for grouting, Paint, and Galvanized Iron to repair the valleys of the roof. I can attend to the building part, the painting, and the grouting, but a tinsmith should do the roof repair. You will recall that I stated this in my estimates. This work should be done in the dry weather and not left until the late Fall.

The log house is to be converted into the workshop, but until the Refrigerators are installed I must keep the ice. Will you enquire into this?

Another item in the estimates was the Insulation. The best time to do this is while the pupils are out on their holidays.

Has the Beatty tender of $134.00 for drinking bowls, tank & piping been accepted?

Mr Harry Leader asked me if I would agree to accept the services of a local carpenter to assist me in the building programme. I told him I had no objection to this providing that his wages did not come out the grant already set apart for improvements to this school.

I shall be glad if you will call the attention of the Department to the items not yet authorized.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones

Ottawa, Ontario,
July 23, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 19th instant enclosing letter dated the 18th instant from the principal of the Portage la Prairie Residential School.

As you are now aware, the materials for repairs requested in your letter of April 11 have been ordered from Gibb, McCaig & Ellwood, Limited, at a cost of $797.53. As an amount of $2,000 was provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at this school, there is still an amount of $1,202.47 available.

Please let me know the approximate amount that would be required to pay for the services of the tinsmith. At the same time you should state the name and address of the tinsmith whom you would recommend be employed. Upon receipt of this information, the question of engaging a tinsmith will receive immediate attention.

I have reviewed our file, but am unable to locate the Beatty tender of $134 for drinking bowls, tank and piping. I would appreciate your forwarding a copy of this.

In the principal's letter of March 14 forwarded under cover of your letter of March 15, item No. 8 stated that he had received a quotation of $200 from the Cook Construction Company for insulation of ceiling with wood wool. I cannot find that this tender has been forwarded here. Please obtain it and send it to me for consideration.

J. Waite, Esq.
With reference to the refrigeration, you forwarded with your letter of March 15, 1938, a quotation dated February 25, 1938, from the Manitoba Power Commission, quoting a price of $703.60 for suitable refrigeration installation. However, this letter stated that the price just mentioned was only good until March 31, and as our funds were not available at that time, no action was taken. Please let me know at once if this price still holds good. If so, you should forward a letter from the Manitoba Power Commission to that effect.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Ottawa,
July 28, 1938.

Dear Sir:

In my letter of the 23rd instant I requested information regarding the request of the Principal for the services of a tinsmith at the Portage la Prairie Residential School. I have no doubt I will hear from you in that regard within a reasonable time.

Yesterday we received an inquiry in connection with the employment of a carpenter. While we have arranged for the purchase of material no authority has yet been given for the hiring of any labour. I was under the impression that the work was being done by the school staff. Please let me know at once if any tradesmen other than the tinsmith will be necessary. If so, you should state the tradesmen required and the approximate length of time that their services would be necessary.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Memorandum:

MR. PRATT

I desire to refer to your telephone communication to Mr. Phelan in regard to the purchase of refrigerators for the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

In the fall of 1937 when forwarding his estimates for the fiscal year 1936-39 the Principal requested that we provide funds for the purchase of refrigerators as there was no cold storage equipment in the school and it was very much required.

Naturally we requested him to let us have an estimate of the probable cost of refrigerators in order that we could decide whether or not the amount could be included in the estimates. He supplied this information and when funds were available we wrote to the Principal requesting him to let us have full details regarding the refrigerators required. He replied by forwarding the quotations which have been sent to the Purchasing Agent.

We did not request him to secure prices but no doubt what happened is that when we asked him to give us an estimate of the cost of the refrigerators he consulted one or more firms with a view to determining what was necessary. It follows that these firms knew that he was requesting refrigerating equipment and, therefore, submitted quotations to him. In replying to our letter asking details of the equipment required he considered that the most satisfactory way would be to forward us the quotations he had received.

Dear Sir:

The Minister's office has received an inquiry regarding representations claimed to have been made regarding repairs required to the sewage disposal plant at the Portage la Prairie Residential School.

No such representations have been received by this Branch. The last reference that we have on file regarding the sewage disposal system at this school is contained in a letter received from you in the latter part of September, 1937. This was in reply to my letter to you of September 15, 1937. At that time you stated that there was no serious complaint from anyone regarding the sewage disposal system.

Please arrange to visit this school at the earliest possible date and let me have a complete report. You should keep in mind that in view of the dissolution of Parliament it is impossible for me to state at the present time what funds will be available during the fiscal year 1940-41.

Dear Sir,

Re Sewage Disposal Portage School.

In reply to your letter 127-1-5 dated February 8th, 1940, I would refer you to Mr. Gow's report which I forwarded with my letter 208-11 A.U., dated Sept. 4, 1936.

I was at the school yesterday and found the situation to be as described by Mr. Gow. The system operates and Mr. Jones states the tank is cleaned out each fall.

In 1936, I understand, the Crescent Lake was used as the outlet for other sewage systems. However, such is not the case today as these have all been eliminated at considerable cost. We, apparently, are the only offenders.

Mr. Gow closes his report by stating it will cost $1650.00 to modernize the disposal system. I doubt if the city would be satisfied with allowing any overflow to pass into the lake. I believe a disposal field is advocated.

I would like to suggest that Mr. Gow thoroughly investigate the situation and submit a report, outlining the system most suitable and acceptable to the city of Portage la Prairie, at the same time stating the entire cost of the work.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Sewage Disposal, Portage LaPrairie Indian Residential School

In reference to Dr. McGill's memorandum of March 5th last regarding sewage disposal at the above mentioned school, enclosed herewith are two copies of a report which has been submitted by Mr. Gow.

It will be noted that at present sewage, and kitchen and laundry waste from the school are discharged through a septic tank into Crescent Lake and that the Manitoba Health Department does not consider the situation to be detrimental to the health of Portage La Prairie residents. The lake has now been developed as a Park area and odours which arise from the discharge are considered to be objectionable. The school cannot be connected to the town sewerage system and the use of a disposal bed, if it could be operated satisfactorily during the severe winters which is doubtful, would involve pumping from the septic tank to the disposal bed.

Mr. Gow suggests that the old sewer line and septic tank be repaired and used only for the kitchen and laundry waste and that a new septic tank and sewer line be built to care for the sewage. Both tanks would discharge into the lake without disposal beds, but it is felt that better septic tank action would be obtained and that the offensive odours would be reduced to a large extent. The cost of this work, including $200.00 for engineering and contingencies, is estimated to be $2,000.00.

As under present conditions expenditures should be held as low as possible and as the health of the public does not appear to be endangered in any way, we concur in Mr. Gow's recommendation and suggest that the Indian Affairs Branch be requested to provide the necessary funds as soon as possible.

Encl.

Kindly return the attached plan as soon as it has served your purpose.

Respectfully submitted,

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,

Sir,

Re - Indian Residential School at Portage la Prairie, Manitoba

Early in 1935 we were asked to report upon the condition of the sewage disposal system at the above mentioned school, following complaints about the disagreeable odor coming from the effluent. Under date of June 29, 1935, we reported upon the situation and pointed out that inasmuch as the Health Department of Manitoba had reported that the situation was not detrimental to the health of the citizens of Portage la Prairie or such as to warrant any apprehension, we did not consider any alterations essential. We again reported upon the situation under date of March 11, 1936, at the request of the Department of Indian Affairs, following complaints they had received. Again we reported that it was not considered necessary to make any alterations or extensions. Under date of August 31, 1936, we reported upon the matter, following request from the Inspector of Indian Agencies, at Winnipeg that we examine the situation at the school, in view of the difficulty of operation reported by the Principal of the school. In this report we outlined the conditions at the school and included suggestions as to temporary work that should be carried out and recommended modernization of the system during the holiday season of 1937. I understand that the temporary work was partially carried out by the school management and that there has not been undue operating trouble experienced since. There was no action on the modernization of the system.

It would appear as if Crescent Lake, into which the effluent discharges, was at one time a sweeping curve of the Assiniboine River and that the altered course of the river left a marshy river bed encircling a large area of wooded land. The Parks Board of Portage la Prairie developed this enclosed area as a park and by pumping from the river maintain water in the old watercourse during the summer. The Indian School is outside the limits of the town as is also that portion of the artificial lake into which the school discharges its sewage. The Parks Board claim to have eliminated the discharge of sewage into the lake except from the Indian School, and the complaints as to the offensive odors from the effluent from the school originate with this Board.

We are enclosing a print of plan showing school site in relation to Crescent Lake, also the location of septic tank catch-basin, manholes and sewer outlets. The profile is based partly upon information furnished by the School Principal. The road between school site and lake is a public roadway not extensively used, but in the route to the pumping plant of the Town of Portage la Prairie. The school is over a mile from the town limits and the town's sewage system does not cover the four

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
westerly blocks of the town, as the main trunk system is inadequate to carry any additional load, the sewerage from the area would have to be pumped and furthermore the area is only sparsely occupied. Owing to the distance from the town's system, the fact that there is insufficient fall from school to the town's system to utilize gravity, and the excessive cost, it is considered impractical to connect the sewage system at the school to the Portage la Prairie sewage system.

Owing to the elevation at which the drains must leave the school and the level to which a septic tank must be constructed, it will be out of the question to discharge the effluent to any disposal bed, except by pumping. We are opposed to passing kitchen and laundry wastes through a septic tank into a disposal bed, and our experience with tile disposal beds at Indian Schools, under our severe winter conditions prevailing here, has been such as to discourage us from suggesting any new installations. It is suggested, therefore, that the kitchen and laundry drainage at this school be separated from the sewage drain and passed through the existing outside drain to septic tank and then discharged into Crescent Lake as at present. The present septic tank will be repaired and fitted with manholes for cleaning, etc. The drain to septic tank will be examined, the catch basin will be replaced by manhole, fitted with screen. A new septic tank will be constructed of sufficient size and depth to care for the sewage from the school. The drain from this new tank will connect with the drain from the old septic tank and the effluent discharged into Crescent Lake. The second tank is considered advisable because of the small size of the old tank, its condition and the desirability of separating kitchen and laundry wastes from the sewerage. No disposal bed will be provided.

The writer had a meeting with the Parks Board of Portage la Prairie, the Town Engineer being present, and four other members including the Chairman. At this meeting members were asked to state the grounds upon which they made complaints re the Indian School and what they wished done. They explained that prior to six or seven years ago, there were no complaints regarding offensive odors from the sewage drain at the school and that the septic tank cannot be operating properly. Asked if they would be satisfied if we built a new modern septic tank and lowered the outlet, they stated they would - if it would eliminate all offensive odors. It was then explained that such odors could not be entirely eliminated without the construction of a tile disposal field; that I was not prepared to recommend the construction of such a field because it necessitated pumping of the effluent and we had no assurance that the disposal bed could be successfully operated. It was pointed out to the Board that no complaint had ever been made by the Municipality in which the school is situated, as to offensive odors; that the Sanitary Inspector of the Manitoba Department of Health had reported that the system met their requirements; that the Medical Health Officer of the Town of Portage la Prairie had taken frequent samples of water from the vicinity of the outlet from the school and found no contamination and that any system of sewage disposal, regardless of cost, with the possible exception of a successfully operated tile disposal bed, was bound to have some disagreeable odors associated with the system. It was explained to the Board that we were prepared to recommend to Ottawa that the work, as outlined above, be carried out this summer and while they were not being asked to approve of such measures, we wished them to know that what was being proposed should go far in eliminating grounds for future complaints.
complaints regarding the sewage system at the school. The members of the Board said they did not want to take any unreasonable stand and considered that if the work, as outlined, was carried out, it was all that could reasonably be expected, in view of the heavy expenditures being incurred in connection with war costs.

On the plan accompanying this letter we have shown in red, an outline of what work should be undertaken - this work being as follows:

1. Separation of laundry and kitchen drainage from sewage system within the school building.

2. Uncovering existing drain from building to septic tank, rebuilding catch basin, repairing septic tank and providing manhole for cleaning, and also uncovering and extending drain from tank to lake.

3. Construction of new septic tank with 4,000 cubic feet capacity, with manholes together with drains to and from tank, as shown on the plan. This tank will not be built of reinforced concrete but will have wooden top, wooden manholes and no syphons.

The separation of laundry and kitchen drainage from the sewage will probably involve considerable work as kitchen and laundry are at opposite ends of the building. It will probably be preferable to construct a new drain outside the building and connect the kitchen drainage and laundry drainage to it, rather than attempt to lay new drain under the floor the entire length of the building. It is realized that uncovering these pipes in the building may reveal much work that should be done and hence the difficulty of estimating the cost of this part of the work.

The gradient of the drain in the school is very flat and the same is true of the drain from the building to septic tank. Stoppages are of frequent occurrence and it may be necessary to increase the gradient outside the building; if uncovering of drain reveals the gradient too flat. It is difficult to accurately estimate the cost of modernizing the old layout, but much work has to be done.

The new tank will possibly not be fitted with syphon chamber and the construction will be as simple as possible with no reinforced concrete being used.

The estimated minimum cost of separating kitchen and laundry drainage from sewage system is $250.00, the cost of modernizing existing layout is $450.00, while the cost of new septic tanks and connecting drains is $1,100.00. The total estimated cost is $1,800.00, so that $2,000.00 should be provided to allow for engineering expenses and contingencies.

Preparation of plans of septic tank will be proceeded with, but as the other work depends largely upon conditions of which little is definitely known at present, no detailed drawings will be prepared prior to the work being undertaken. If the work suggested is authorized, it should be undertaken in early July, while the pupils are away and before harvest gets under way.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Leader:

Your letter of May 29, addressed to the Minister, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

When you visited my office yesterday afternoon, I discussed with you the subject matter of a report submitted to the Department by the District Chief Engineer, on the sewage disposal system at the Portage school. Mr. Gow, in his report, states:

"owing to the elevation at which the drains must leave the school and the level to which a septic tank must be constructed, it would be out of the question to discharge the effluent to any disposal bed, except by pumping. ... The present septic tank will be repaired and fitted with man-holes for cleaning, etc., and a new septic tank will be constructed of sufficient size and depth to care for the sewage from the school. No disposal bed will be provided."

Mr. Gow refers to a meeting he had with the Parks Board of Portage la Prairie, with the Town Engineer present. When asked if they would be satisfied if the Department built a new modern septic tank and lowered the outlet, they stated they would, if it would eliminate all offensive odors. I am not of course an engineer and hesitate to pass judgment on this matter, but I am not at all sure that the members of the Parks Board would be satisfied if we built a new septic tank while the effluent still continued to be discharged into the little lake. Mr. Gow it would appear, explained to the members of the Board that this repair work, when completed, would not wholly eliminate the offensive odors.

Mr. Gow estimates that the repair work would cost approximately $2,000.00, and, in view of the fact that his report did not reach the Department until May 9, it was impossible to include an appropriation for this work in the present year's estimates. I cannot state at this moment if

it is -

Ottawa, September 13, 1940.

Re: Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Leader:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 9th instant, in which you express regret at the failure of the Department to undertake certain repairs to the sewage disposal plant at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

I have had two letters recently from the Council of the City of Portage la Prairie, urging us to undertake these repairs. This matter has been discussed very fully and in detail with the authorities of the United Church. If I remember correctly, I intimated to you when you called at my office that no provision was made in the estimates of this year for the repairs that appear to be necessary at the Portage School. In view of this fact, it is simply impossible for us to proceed with the work. If conditions are bad and if they are likely to become more objectionable, we shall have to seriously consider closing the school. A month or two ago the water system at the Brandon Residential School became inadequate to meet the needs of the institution and in order to repair it we had to abandon the construction of the Ahousaht School at the Pacific Coast. This will give you an idea of how limited the funds at our disposal actually are.

I have no assurance at this date that we

Harry Leader, Esq., M.P.,
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.
shall be able to include in the estimates of next year a sum sufficient to remodel the sewage disposal plant at Portage. It is altogether likely that you will be communicating with the office of the Minister in respect to the matter. If you do this, the claims of the Portage School will be very carefully and very sympathetically reviewed.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Re Sewage Disposal Plant at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of 19th Ult. addressed to Mr. O. A. Ditchfield with respect to the above matter.

Your letter was read in open council and the members expressed disappointment that no action is being taken to remove what the City Council considers a menace to the public health.

We would point out the fact that this sewage passes through a septic tank that has been in operation for many years, into an artificial lake that is maintained by the city at considerable cost, and is used for boating etc.

It does seem unfair that odors, which unmistakably exist, should be permitted to interfere with the full enjoyment of what we consider one of the city's principal recreation centers. You mention that no complaint has been received from the municipality in which this property is situated. May I point out that the entire lake bottom is owned and controlled by the City of Portage la Prairie.

As before mentioned this particular septic tank has been in operation for many years. Unquestionably it
has outlasted its usefulness and is now depositing raw sewage into the lake.

The situation is a topic of much discussion among our ratepayers and they are urging us to do our utmost to see that some remedy is applied.

We respectfully urge that the question be reopened and given further consideration at Ottawa.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Secretary-Treasurer.

Memorandum: Mr. Wardle

Re - Sewage Disposal, Portage La Prairie Indian Residential School

In reference to your notation on Dr. McGill's memorandum to you of February 26th last, I may say that Mr. Gow was informed accordingly.

Regarding Dr. McGill's statement that representations had been received that the work should begin as soon as possible, Mr. Gow states as follows:

"The work involved includes the separation of the laundry and kitchen drainage from the ordinary sewage and also the cutting off of the sewage outlet from the school itself. Under any circumstances there is bound to be some inconvenience caused to those in charge of the school but it is considered that the least inconvenience would result if the work were carried out in July when the majority of the Indian children are away from the Institution on holidays. Conditions at the school are not any more serious now than they have been for many years past, so there does not appear to be any necessity for the carrying out of this work before July."

Unless there have been recent developments of which we have not been informed, we agree with Mr. Gow that the summer holidays would be the most suitable time for carrying out the work.

Respectfully submitted,

With reference to the above, I have to report that the above named complainant called this office by phone at 10:00 P.M., of the 14-4-41, & stated that one set of harnesses was missing from the stable at the Ind school, & he had made a thorough search for same but could not locate them, & he believed that same had been stolen & requested Police investigation.

2. I patrolled per P.C.8085, to the Ind school this A.M., where the complaint was interviewed. He stated that the harness in question had been hanging on pegs in the stable behind two horses, which owing to sickness had not been worked since April 8th, 1941, & therefore the harness had not been used since then. Since the farm instructor, Alec ROXBURGH, had reported to him on the 14-4-41, that the harness was missing from the stable, & after he had made a thorough search of the premises without success he had decided that it had been stolen. The harness is described as follows:

One set heavy harness (make unknown) colour black, black steel harness, straps attached, blue coloured brow bands with brass dots, new heel chain attached to one end of one trace, old set, much repaired. Value £20.00.

3. Alec ROXBURGH was next interviewed & stated that the harness had not been used since April 8th, & thought he had seen the harness hanging on the pegs on Friday morning 11-4-41, & found them missing on Saturday Morning the 12-4-41, but thought that Mr. JONES had taken them for repairs, so he did not report the matter to Mr. JONES until the 15-4-41. He further stated that the doors of the Ind stable are never locked. He gave the following statement:

Statement of Alec ROXBURGH, Farm Inst., Ind School, Portage La Prairie.

I am Farm Instructor at the Indian School Portage La Prairie. We have two sets of harness in the stable, but only one set is used every day. On Sunday April 12/41 I noticed that one set of harness was missing from the usual pegs. I am not certain but I thought the harness was there on Friday morning April 11th. This set of harness had not been used since April 8th, 1941. I thought Mr. JONES, the Principal had taken the harness to be repaired, so I did not say anything to him until Monday April 14th, at which time I asked him if he had taken the harness for repairs & he replied that he had not. I saw Jim DANIELS in the boys lavatory in the school on Thursday night, April 10th, but did not see any of the Indians around the school on Friday night April 11th. I don't know of any suspects, but it would appear to be the work of some Ind who knew the routine of the stable.

Signed: A. ROXBURGH.

4. It was learned from Mr ROXBURGH that two Indians boys of the school (Wallace JOHNSON & Michael PASHA) had been in the habit of using this harness on the two horses prior to the time when it had been taken out of use on April 8th. These two boys were interrogated at length, but no information of value could be obtained from them. They both stated that they had seen the harness on the pegs in the stable on Friday morning April 11th but had not seen it since that time. They also stated that Indians from The Long Plains Reserve are often at the school to visit their boys, both during the day & night, & they were in the habit of taking their horses to the stable at the school to water them when they came with wagons & teams, but they had not seen any grown up Indians around the school on Friday April 11th.

5. The harness in question was hung on pegs close to the door of the stable (the doors of which are never secured), which is situated approx 50 yds to the East of a main travelled road to Portage a distance of one mile. The fields North, South & West of the building are water soaked & impassable. It would appear that this theft has been committed by some Indian from the Long Plains Ind Reserve who it is reported come to visit their children at the school any time they wish & tie their horses outside the stable & also go to the stable where the harness was kept to water their horses, & some person who knew that the particular set of harness was not in use. A number of the boys at the school was questioned by the writer & Mr JONES in an effort to learn whether any Indians were around the buildings on the night in question, but without avail.

6. In view of the fact that JIM DANIELS, of the Long Plains Ind Reserve was seen in the school on Thursday April 10th & knowing that he does not have very good reputation, I patrolled per P.O.905, with Cst. Wrightson, to the Long Plains Reserve to further investigate this matter. Jim DANIELS was interrogated & admitted that he was at the school on April 10th to visit some of the boys, but had not been there since & he denied any knowledge of the harness. A thorough search of his premises was carried out but the harness in question could not be found. Further enquiries were made on the Reserve & Mr SAWER, the farm instructor interviewed, but no information of value could be obtained. Mr SAWER stated that he would keep a lookout for the harness in question & notify this office if he obtains any information.

7. On the return of the patrol to Portage further enquiries were made around the Indian school district & Settlers interviewed but no additional information was forthcoming. All second-hand stores & Junk stores at Portage were checked but the harness could not be seen or any trace of it found. The Portage City Police have been given a description of the harness & will keep a lookout for same. Harness will be inspected during patrols in the dist.

8. Investigation will be continued in this matter & further report will follow.

Dear Sir:

Re: Sewage Disposal, Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 22nd with reference to the above mentioned project and asking for particulars as to the method of eliminating the sewer gas from the kitchens of the school.

Part of the work carried out during 1941 included the laying of a 4" drain to discharge all wastes from the kitchen into the catch basin outside the building. This drain also carried the discharge from water closets, wash basins and baths in the staff quarters above the kitchen and much of the plumbing in connection with the same passed through the kitchen. The connection to the main sewer line running the length of the building under the floor had been broken and sealed with the laying of this 4" drain. All sinks, wash basins, water closets and etc., leading into this drain are trapped. No trap, however, was placed in the new 4" drain for this would have necessitated a manhole just outside the building since it has been found that such traps frequently become plugged and access to the same must be provided. The drain discharges into the old catch basin at an elevation slightly above the drain outletting to the old septic tank. The catch basin is provided with a metal cover which is not air-tight.

Our inspection in January confirmed the complaints received regarding the sewer gas in the kitchen and it was evident that this gas could only come from leakage through the plumbing in the kitchen after backing up from the old septic tank to the catch basin and thence into and through the new 4" drain to the kitchen plumbing. We had no desire to bring in plumbers to go over all the old traps and plumbing in order to locate the point at which the sewer gas was leaking. It was decided to trap the 4" drain at its outlet into the catch basin although the pipe only protruded 1/2" from the face of the concrete. This was accomplished by having made at a cost of $1.50, a galvanised elbow to fit over the 4" protruding pipe and insert downward into the liquid which stands in the basin below the outletting pipe. The so-called contraction is only temporary inasmuch as 1/2" does not provide as much holding surface as several inches. However, it has remained in place and the sewer gas in the kitchen has been eliminated. The school authorities should clean out this catch basin twice yearly and at such time it will be necessary to remove and replace the elbow which is a few minutes labour only.

You mentioned in the last paragraph of your letter that the Director of Indian Affairs had hoped that the work would be of a permanent nature. He apparently has in mind the work carried out at the Portage la Prairie Indian School during 1941.

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6273, file 583-5, part 7)

We should realize, however, that the purpose of the work carried out at the school during 1941 was not to overhaul the plumbing to locate and repair leaks or to do work necessary to overcome the plugging of water closets and etc. It was to reduce the disagreeable odor arising from the sewer outlet at its entrance into Crescent Lake and the pollution of Crescent Lake itself - conditions which had been the source of many complaints during recent years from Portage la Prairie organizations. It is true that the partial separation of laundry and kitchen drainage from the main sewer system did relieve the situation somewhat within the school, yet the sewer system in the school continued to be very unsatisfactory. The main sewer running the length of the building is laid at too flat an angle and the connecting pipes emptying into it have very little slope so that at times of overloading, plugging of the lines results, creating unsatisfactory conditions. We were always careful to point out that the work we were carrying out was not for the purpose of overcoming these conditions. These conditions, insofar as the laundry and kitchen drainage is concerned, were eliminated but they still exist in the sewer lines and the correction of the same will necessitate the tearing up of the flooring and the complete realignment of the main sewer and connecting sewers to it within the building itself. This will entail a great deal of expense as it is an expensive job.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) D. B. Gow,

GENERAL REMARKS

Be sure to have the paint well brushed out.

Trouble results from paint being applied too thick; three thin coats are better than two thick ones.

Three or more days should be allowed between coats for drying.

See that the oil used for thinning is pure raw linseed oil.

Be sure to stir the paint up well. The proper way to stir paint is to box it, that is, pour it back and forth from one can to another until it is thoroughly mixed.

By following the above directions good results will be obtained.

We recommend the employment of a first class painter.

QUANTITY REQUIRED

To estimate the quantity of Diamond A Absolutely Pure Paint required for two coats, measure the distance around the building, multiply by the average height, which will give the number of square feet to paint. Divide this number by 400 (the number of square feet Diamond A Absolutely pure Paint will cover, two coats to the gallon) and this will give you approximately the number of gallons of paint to buy for the body. Then multiply this number with this quantity, which will give you the amount needed for the cornices, trimmings, waste, etc. To estimate the amount for floors, ceilings, etc., divide the number of square feet by 400 as before, which will give you the quantity needed.

Of course it will be understood that surfaces vary in their natures and that this estimate is based on a surface of the ordinary good condition to receive paint.

QUALITY PRICE ECONOMY

The actual outlay of money in painting work can only be measured by the net cost of the completed job.

In the first place, it costs as much to apply an inferior paint as a good one, and the cost of the application is much more than the cost of the material used. Comparing the covering capacity of Diamond A Absolutely Pure Paint (400 square feet, two coats to the gallon) with the advertised covering capacity of cheaper priced paints (usually 300 to 350 square feet, two coats) and it will be found that the actual first cost or actual outlay of money is less for Diamond A Absolutely Pure Paint than for the inferior grades, and besides the additional saving in applying fewer coats there is also the vast saving in the durability or preserving qualities. Every package of Diamond A Absolutely Pure Paint is thoroughly tested as to quality, color and consistency, and each package bearing our label is the unqualified guarantee of quality and satisfactory results from its use when properly used.

THE J. H. ASHDOWN HARDWARE CO., LIMITED WINNIPEG

Saskatoon - Regina - Edmonton - Calgary

PAINT PROTECTION

Paint is a necessity and should not be clasped as a luxury, although it is a luxury to have everything around a home bright and clean. The cost of painting is actually less than the inevitable wear and tear of any surfaces which are left without proper protection. Protecting it is one luxury which costs nothing to indulge in.

It is a heavy expense not to paint, and no expense to keep well painted every surface exposed to the elements.

As a general rule a property owner gives very little attention to the painting of his house except from the standpoint of appearance; of course it is desirable that property should have a bright and clean air, but the greatest value of paint is for protection. It is most essential and compared to the great cost of the inevitable replacements when left unpainted, the cost is actually nothing.

All surfaces must be satisfied and kept so; the elements are always seeking a weak point of attack, and unless kept thoroughly protected, decay and destruction soon follow.

MACHINE-MADE PAINTS Versus HAND-MIXED PAINTS

THEN AND NOW

Years ago, paints as mixed by the painter, consisted of two ingredients, white lead and linseed oil. There is still some paint of this character used, but a great deal more than formerly as new scientific, chemical tests and thorough research work have developed that a paint made from pure carbamate of lead and linseed oil is not the most satisfactory or durable paint coating.

INGREDIENTS THAT MAKE A GOOD PAINT

Pure white lead and linseed oil are good as far as they go, but they do not go far enough. It is an acknowledged fact that white lead when mixed alone with linseed oil has a tendency to powder and chalk. Zinc added gives eight protection counteracts this action. Zinc also increases the covering power of the paint, and, when used with white lead and linseed, appears to be the only quality that makes it take the coloring matter readily. White lead and zinc oxide, further, on account of their high refractive power, enable the manufacturer to incorporate the largest possible quantity of linseed oil in the mixture of paint, and, as is well known, linseed oil gives life and elasticity to the paint.

It is therefore important that a good prepared paint shall contain pure zinc oxide and linseed oil, and it is equally important that these three ingredients should be put together in the correct proportions.
