Special Work

Occasionally a job is in such condition that no paint will give satisfactory results when applied in the ordinary way. In such cases we invite correspondence and will give directions for special treatment.

Number of Coats

To secure best results, new work should have three coats, that is, two besides the priming coat. The latter should be sufficient to give a generous efficiency to the paint. For old work, as a rule two coats are sufficient, unless the old paint is practically all gone, in which case three are better.

One Gallon of "Diamond A" Absolutely Pure Paint, Covers 400 to 500 Square Feet, Two Coats

Directions for Use

New Work

Shake all knots and sticky spots before applying. The priming coat is the most important. Do not prime with oil, as the succeeding coat will not adhere to it. Prime with Diamond A absolutely pure paint; reduce with pure raw linseed oil, 1/2 pint to a gallon of paint. After priming allow at least 36 hours to dry; putty all nail holes carefully.

Second Coat

For the second coat, add a pint of pure spirits of turpentine to each gallon of paint.

Third Coat

The third, or finishing coat, should always be applied as the paint comes in the original can. All coats must be well brushed out.

Old Work

When the surface is porous and has not been painted for a long time, it should be treated the same as new work; the paint must be removed from the surface by using steel brushes or scrapers. Old surfaces that have been exposed to coal smoke, chimney door jambs, etc., should be thoroughly scoured. Where the surface is in fair condition, add one pint of turpentine to each gallon of paint for the first coat; also the second. If three coats are applied, finish the same as new work.

Re: Paint and Beds for Fortage Residential School.

I acknowledge your letter 127-1-25, dated May 7th regarding the above matters. On May 13th I visited the school as requested.

The Department will recall that interior paint was supplied for this school last year and the improvement in the building is most gratifying. Two thirds of the interior of the school has been painted. All has had two coats and in some rooms three coats were required to give a good finish. All work done up-to-date has been for the benefit of the children; no paint has been used on the staff rooms or on the Principal's suite. The work is not yet completed and at present Mr. McNeill has two good painters working full time.

The outbuildings have not been painted for many years - perhaps twenty; however, they are in good repair and if possible should be painted. Mr. McNeill points out that these are Government buildings, yet he is prepared to spend funds on wages for painting if the Government will provide the paint. Mr. McNeill points out the decision rests entirely with the Department; but if they wish the work done the paint must be provided at once before the men now engaged finish the interior work and leave. I think more buildings throughout the country would be painted if the cost was only a question of the purchase of paint. I can only add that the buildings need painting and the painters now engaged are doing excellent work.

The double-deck beds were requested to provide more floor space and thus make it easier for the children to reach the fire escapes in case of fire. At present I consider the beds are too close together and that they cause a fire hazard. However, after going into this matter carefully, I think the number could be reduced to four beds complete with mattresses. I find the school now has eight - thirty-six inch beds not in use because they have no mattresses. These beds would accommodate two small boys each. A number of the boys are brothers and thus there should be no objection to the arrangement. Some of these thirty-six" beds could also be used in the infirmary, thus releasing smaller beds for the dormitories. I am changing the requisition to read as follows:

4 - double deck beds complete with mattresses,
6 - 36" mattresses, standard length.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Enclos.

December 10, 1943.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

The Fire Commissioner of Manitoba in his report on the Portage Residential School recommends that two wooden type fire escapes equipped with hand rails be built from the balcony of the second floor to the balcony of the first floor. At present there are two poles as a means of escape and these are condemned. It is pointed out that if the main stairway were cut off by fire or hot gasses, there is a possibility that the fire escapes could not be used by the children in the senior dormitory. I have obtained a quotation for the construction of the two stairways from Messrs. Gibb and Ellwood Co. Ltd., Portage la Prairie, and inclose same herewith. The cost complete, except the painting of the stairs, which can be done by the staff, is $115.00. I would strongly recommend that this work be done as soon as possible.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 14, 1943.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of December 10, in which you intimate that the Provincial Fire Commissioner recommends the installation of two wooden type fire escapes, equipped with hand rails, at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, from the balcony of the second floor to the balcony of the first floor. It is noted that the cost of this work is not likely to exceed $115.00.

In view of the large number of Indian day and residential schools destroyed by fire during the last two year period, we are anxious that everything humanly possible should be done to protect our buildings from fire. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would take the steps necessary to have this work undertaken at the earliest convenient date.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum

We have your memorandum of the 1st instant, your file No. 127-1-5, with reference to hot water boiler for the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, and note that the Indian Agent now requests that a Safford Bungalow Heater B-32, rating 400 cubic feet be supplied by Mr. Gordon McKay, instead of the Gurney Heater described on your requisition of June 27. Inspected by E.H. Houston

Fire Hazards Observed

3. Door and frame leading from boiler room has not been covered with metal.

4. Ordinary combustible paper is used to cover hot air pipes in the school building annex.

Fire Prevention Orders Issued

Combustible wall and table in the dispensary to be protected from electric hot plate with a sheet of asbestos board and metal.

Door leading from boiler room to outside to be equipped with a self-closing device.

Door and frame of boiler room to hallway to be covered with metal on the boiler room side.

Use only asbestos paper for covering hot air pipes in annex building.

The new Principal, Rev.A.C. Huston, of the Portage la Prairie Residential School has made request to have certain changes made to the windows of his residence which is a suite in the school, also redecorating of the suite.

It is many years since the suite was decorated and although it is still in good shape I think it should be done. At least three Principals have been in residence here since it was re-decorated.

The cost of changing the windows is $118.00. This price was furnished by Mr.Haid. The cost of decorating, labour only $250.00. Paint, varnish, etc.$50.00. The cost of the paper, chosen by the Principal's wife is quoted at $58.80.

The Principal is very anxious to have this work done as he has been supplied with a quantity of very fine furniture by the Women's Missionary Society.

I also obtained a price for cutting two doors into the playrooms. The cutting of these doors will allow the children to go immediately into the playroom instead of walking up flight of stairs. This would save stairs which are showing signs of wear and would keep the children out of the main halls. The price of this work will be $195.00, labour and material.

Will you please advise in this matter.

Indian Agent

With reference to the above noted letter and further to my report of the 12th. idem, I wish to enclose herewith a report and costs of repairs to the windows at the Portage Indian Residential School. There is also an estimate for a storm porch to be built at the main entrance of the building. While this is not absolutely necessary at this time it should be considered. In regard to the repairs to the windows, this is a very necessary repair. The original windows on the ground floor were one piece of glass 32 X 34. As these windows were constantly being broken and were very costly to replace, a series of Principals gradually boarded them up, until all the windows in the boys' lavatory have been boarded up. It is the same in the dining room and the girls' portion. It is suggested that smaller windows be installed, - 9 lights to each window. A window broken would then not be too expensive to repair. During the years, sand from the road has blown into the frames and water has caused some, in fact most of the window frames, to rot and replacements will have to be made. Last year I was able to have glass replaced in all the doors without expense to the Department. The replacing of the glass in the windows is too expensive for the school to undertake. I would strongly recommend that the repairs be done, the school is gradually improving in appearance through the efforts of the present Principal, who is very anxious to co-operate in any scheme for the benefit of the pupils and the condition of the school generally.

There is still an expensive repair to be done on the
eavestroughing and the roof. It seems impossible to obtain prices for the repair of the eavestroughing which should be done while the scaffolding is erected for the painting. I would also be pleased if the Department would furnish the name of the firm who laid the roof. It is a tiled roof, the building was built in 1915. There appears to be no records at the agency office in regard to the building. It will be necessary to have the roof repaired as it is leaking badly in places. There is a possibility that the whole roof will have to be replaced; I would, however, be pleased to receive advice from the firm who laid the roof in the first place.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Having inspected the above building on December 1st 1945, re: fire protection, I would strongly recommend the following.

(1) New hose, to replace that which is in service at present on the hose reels, as it is unfit for further service.

(2) Three 2½ gal. Soda-acid Fire extinguisher, be placed in basement, as there are no extinguishers there at the present time.

(3) On the ground floor there are two foam type extinguishers, these should be replaced by the soda-acid type.

(4) 300ft. of 2½" cotton, rubber lined hose, (1) hydrant key, and (1) nozzle with ½" tip should be supplied for use on outside hydrant, this would give protection to the out buildings.

(5) 1- lqt., vaporizing liquid extinguisher, should be placed in laundry.

(6) Fire exit doors should be marked by signs and red lights, as the sleeping quarters are badly over crowded, 24 beds in one room 26ft X 30ft; the beds being only about three or four inches apart, with one bed blocking the exit door, but there was no other place for it.

(7) Stovepipes from kitchen stove should be renewed, and the ceiling above same be protected by asbestos.

(8) Valves on standpipes should be examined and repacked etc.

(9) The spaces around the steam pipes where they pass through the floors should be covered with metal.

(10) Quarter round should be put around edges of floors wherever necessary.

(11) Two - Soda-acid Fire extinguishers should be placed in the small school room, as this is heated with a hot air furnace in the basement.

Signed Geo. H. Spriggs,
Fire Chief.
During a recent visit to the Portage Residential School, it was noted that one of the hose was in poor condition and I did not feel entirely satisfied with the general condition of the fire fighting equipment. I asked the Fire-Chief of the Portage la Prairie Fire-hall to make a complete inspection and let me have a report on his findings. A copy of his report is enclosed herewith. All hose and connections were tested and condemned. The hose is 2" cotton.

Item 4 deals with a hose and connections for the hydrant in the yard, which the Department pay a rental of $150.00 per year. This hose should be boxed near the hydrant and be ready for immediate use.

The fact of the beds being too close together has been brought to the attention of the Principal. It also has been noted that one bed blocks the passage to the fire escape.

I beg to suggest that items, Nos. 1 to 5 be purchased by the Department, including item No.11 and that I be allowed to do the necessary fixing suggested in items 6 to 10.

I also beg to request that I be allowed to engage the services of the fire-chief to make a visit to the Sandy Bay School for the purpose of inspecting the fire equipment there. The cost of the inspection at the Portage School will be approximately $5.00 and at the Sandy Bay School possibly $10.00 with an additions expense for travelling. Will you please advise in these matters.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Huston called me this morning about the jacket heater in the school. I dismantled the heater and found the following damage:

Found the boiler corroded rather badly and with a large amount of loose scale and a crack in the boiler at one side of the slice door, running 4" up on the outside, across the bottom and approximately 6" on the inside.

It is my experience that a repair of this nature is seldom satisfactory.

The cause of this damage, in my estimation, is that the scale has banked up under the fire door, causing an uneven heating of the boiler, resulting a strain on the casting and an eventual break. At the outlet of the boiler I took out a piece of scale 3" long and two thirds the size of the outlet.

The size of the boiler is, Triumph Mogul, No. B.32, made by the Dominion Radiators, Serial No. 46004.

I installed this boiler in 1944. The damage is not caused by a faulty boiler, but the water supply in the city having very heavy lime deposits.

I would suggest a new boiler, as I do not think a satisfactory repair can be made on the old one.

Yours faithfully,

J.G. McKay.

Dear Mr. Waite;

An observant visitor to certain of our Indian Residential schools would ask why we have deliberately set out to make our residences such dull and unattractive places. I must confess that it might easily appear that we had done so intentionally. Some schools are as void of light illuminative colors as a medieval dungeon. Where an attempt has been made to introduce color dark brown floors and battleship gray walls has been the answer. The whole appearance is in many cases depressing. Hades could not appear more colorless, drab or forlorn. It would almost appear to the visitor that some other motive rather than the education of the child had possessed us. Have we lost sight of the fact that in the education of a child that its environment should stimulate rather than dull the senses. That brightness, cheerfulness and cleanliness create an atmosphere where little children respond.

Those of us who have had to do with Indians over a period of years know that their existence is often hard and dull and colorless. That children born into this environment and nurtured there until the age of seven come into our schools with minds shadowed by the frustrations of their home existence. It's like accepting a plant that had sprouted in the cellar. It needs the atmosphere of Spring not the dullness of Winter. An Indian child more than the average White child needs to be transplanted into the type of environment that is Spring like in its warmth and color and cheer. His morose and frustrated mind needs to be induced out of its shell and infused with color and light and cheer. Only then will it live above the dissipation of less worthy thoughts.

During my years in the North I discovered that an Indian's dog brought up in a certain way became imured to it, from puppyhood it had only known one manner of life and therefore in adulthood accepted it without protest. I know there are people who would argue keep the school more and more akin to condition on the Reserve because it will not be such a let down for the child who on graduation must return home. I would argue that the school should incorporate factors and means to develop the aesthetic side of the child's nature. This is not done through textbooks but by making his environment attractive. Lacking this there is a very grave danger that the Indian child will grow up like the Indian puppy content forever with life as it is because it is ignorant of a better way. We must make beautiful and attractive the child's environment hoping that time will make him a stranger to anything that is by comparison inferior. Later in life, perhaps on the Reserve the adult will create about him in so far as he can the environment native to his childhood. The hope of creating the inner urge for the betterment of conditions on the reserve lies in the quality of those things learned by the child.
INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

The Woman's Missionary Society
The United Church of Canada

You will agree Mr. Waite that I have attempted since taking charge of the above school a year ago to put this theory into practice. That I came to a school badly in need of attention. The encouraging thing has been that you and through you the Department at Ottawa have responded to my appeals for help in many ways.

In my impatience to make the building presentable in the minimum of time I have spent money I thought could be spared for the purpose from per capita grant and local sources. Board and clothing at the average Indian school can always be improved by greater expenditure, consequently a principal feels guilty diverting even surplus funds to other items.

It will not be necessary for me to enumerate to you who visits the school the various changes that have been wrought. Since your last visit we have redecorated and modernized two rooms with bright paint and light green inlaid linoleum. One of these rooms was the sewing room. It unfortunately is on the dark side of the school and requires artificial light all day. We installed a fluorescent light and the bright walls and floor covering creates a noon day atmosphere. New chairs have been purchased and all sewing machines repaired. The cost was just a fraction over two hundred dollars.

Our main hall or corridor has to be lighted artificially. We had one of our men an amateur at painting go over all the walls, doors and ceiling with white paint. It has made a remarkable difference. Now we would like to have a professional painter go over all the work with a final coat of white. Mr. Green of our city would do the work at one third the price quoted by a local firm last Summer. We would like to see the loose linoleum taken from the floor and put in an upstairs corridor where it is badly needed and inlaid linoleum cemented down in its place. In selecting linoleum for this main hall we would like to have a six foot strip of moss green linoleum run the full length of hall and have a border on either side about six inches wide in a deep red or black.

This should add color and smartness to the very part of our building that is seen by every visitor. Mr. Green will do the painting and supply the labor in laying the linoleum for $100.00. He can do this now at the price I have stated where later on toward Spring the demands upon him are too great. I feel that every year we should aim to smarten up our school by doing something similar to what I now suggest. I have one of our own men painting away at our dormitories but I feel the main hall is work for a professional painter.

On an enclosed sheet I have stated the various things required also quantity and prices of same to carry out the decoration of our main corridor. Would you please present the request I now make to the department at Ottawa that they finance the proposed work. You might also remind them that we do need the linoleum badly and that the only difference between the linoleum I request and any other of similar quality is in the color and not in the price. I remain,

Yours sincerely,

PORTAGE La PRAIRIE, Man.

NEW SEWING MACHINES

We are pleased to announce we can again accept orders for new sewing machines for use in schools, with assurance such orders will be filled within thirty or sixty days.

During the war years, the Singer Factory at St. Johns, P.Q., was completely turned over to war work. Production of new machines is again under way. Shipments are not equal to the tremendous demand, but machine orders for Schools and Institutions are given priority over those for household use.

If your school is in need of new equipment we shall be pleased to hear from you, either direct to us by letter or through our nearest shop. We will be pleased to take care of your order for special cabinet type Electrics designed for schoolroom use - or for regular type treadle machines.

We will allow a credit for any machines traded-in against the purchase of modern electric or new style treadle type.

The former generous discount to schools will again be allowed when the order stipulates the machines are for use in a classroom. There has been no increase in our prices in fifteen years, so the present offers a splendid opportunity to invest in new equipment.

We take this opportunity to advise you our nearest shop will be glad to provide prompt and efficient service in repairing machines now in use. Repair parts for Singer machines are always in stock.

We are not yet in a position to furnish Fashion Aids, such as Electric Irons, Buttonhole attachment, Zipper Feet, Zig-zagger, etc. etc. but we are assured all of these helps to sewing will be available before the opening of your Fall term.

If your teacher is in need of a book of instructions or paper Stitching Charts for Beginners, we shall be pleased to take care of your order. These are furnished free of charge.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

A letter has just been received by our local Agent Mr. Waite from your office in which it is stated that your purchasing agent is unable to procure any other color than brown inlaid linoleum. It also stated that the brown linoleum was being purchased.

In the letter in which I requested this linoleum I went to great length trying to explain that I was trying to get away from dull drab colors within the school by the introduction of bright cheerful colors. It was quite a shock for me to learn that brown linoleum was being sent.

The colored linoleum does not cost one cent more than the brown. I went into the Portage hardware this morning and I saw six full size rolls of colored linoleum. I feel sure that if you granted me permission I could procure the desired colors here in the West.

The way the Department has responded to my appeals from time to time has been very encouraging. It certainly inspires one to do his best but please do not send me brown linoleum.

Could it not be arranged that I could be granted permission to purchase the linoleum. I would of course keep within the price range that governs your purchasing agent. Re: 127-1-5, December 7th, 1945.

I beg to refer to paragraph 4 of Chief Geo. Spriggs, Fire Chief, Portage la Prairie, report on the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

The hydrant mentioned in his report is outside and should have the protection of a house for the hose. This fact was mentioned in the first paragraph of my letter covering the Chief's report.

There is a hydrant house in the yard of the Instructional Centre here, under the direction of D.V.A. I made inquiry about this house in April, at that time the Superintendent was away and I could not obtain definite information about acquiring it. I again visited the centre today and was informed that the matter had been taken up and the Superintendent suggested that the house be taken over as on loan at present. The house is surplus and will not be required at the centre and most likely will be broken up if left there. The cost of building a house would be expensive at the present time and the hose should be housed near the hydrant to be of use in an emergency.

I beg to request authority to hire a truck for the purpose of removing the house to the school and the sum of $35.00 to place a cement base under the house. I estimate the cost of moving the house and setting it on a base would cost approximately $50.00.
The Superintendent is certain the house will never be required, it is surplus and although the house will be taken over as on loan, no further inquiry will be made about it.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 22, 1946.

Dear Mr. Waite:

Enclosed is a copy in triplicate of the estimate of cost to erect a porch over the entrance to the south end of our school residence. The contractor and his well founded reputation will need no introduction to you.

You will note in the estimate the stipulated size and construction of the proposed porch. Its quality and size apart from practical demands must be in keeping with the appearance of the main building. A careful perusal of the enclosed estimate and a mental comparison of prevailing costs should commend the statement to your judgment.

The entrance we propose to have covered by the porch is one being used by all the boys every time anyone of them feels inclined. Through it they go to the classrooms, the workshop, the barn, the skating rink and the playground. The male members of the staff use it continually. All the girls must pass through it at least eight times a day in going back and forth to the classrooms. One might say that the daily traffic of the girls alone is equal to that of four hundred people. The entrance now through wear and lack of repair demands that something be done immediately.

This entrance is just over our grocery store room. It is also right outside the boy's playroom. Since it opens to the outside and is unprotected from the wintry winds it becomes a sort of grief for most of the school year.

The proposed porch would overcome the distress just mentioned. It would have a door in each of its three outside walls so that one could use the door on the side sheltered from the wind. It would protect the steps leading down to the ground level and so eliminate the hazard of slippery steps all during the winter months. It will also provide a place where men and boys can change their barn and field attire before entering the residence. It is close to the skating rink and can be used by all children as a place for changing their footwear.

The general hospital within this city has a porch to their front entrance opening to the south similar in detail to the one I now recommend for our use. I feel if they had to have it that our need is a thousand times greater since we use our entrance just that many times more. After two winter putting up with the problem created by the exposure of our south entrance, I trust a definite move may now be made to adopt my suggested remedy. I remain,

Memorandum:

Re: Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School

In connection with Mr. Heey's memorandum of January 29, 1946 and your notations of February 1st thereon, you are advised as follows:

Our Mr. Margreaves visited the school on June 20, 1946 and carried out an inspection of the Heating, Ventilating & Plumbing services, along with a general check-up of the building structure.

In a brief summary, it can be stated that a general deterioration has taken place in all of the mechanical services. It is apparent that very little maintenance has been carried out for some years, and many parts of the equipment are badly worn and cannot be satisfactorily repaired. The radiation is insufficient to properly heat the building to a temperature of 70° Fahrenheit when the outside temperature is at 30° below zero.

It was particularly noticed throughout the building, however, that everything was meticulously clean and fresh, as regards paint work and general cleanliness.

Going into some detail, the following is an outline of conditions as they exist at the present time.

The steam heating system is a one pipe job, and there is not enough radiation to adequately balance the heat loss. Generally, the radiation is approximately 25% low, with varying discrepancies in different parts of the building. The general layout of piping is of fair design, but in many cases movement, caused by expansion and contraction, has resulted in leaky connections. The radiator air valves are in very poor shape, with every evidence pointing to a serious deterioration in the packing; another cause of leaks. Most valves are without handles; the stems have been mutilated so badly that handles could not be fitted. The radiator air vents have been tampered with so often, that only a few are in their normal upright position, and therefore, are not functioning as intended. No attention has been given to making the necessary provisions for expansion, by the use of offsets, etc.

The boiler is a horizontal return tubular type, enclosed in a brick setting. The brick work has deteriorated badly in places, and the steel front has been cracked over the fire door, and poorly welded. The grates are warped, and are not in good condition. It was stated by the engineer-caretaker, that when Mr. Hose carried out his inspection, and an attempt was made to raise a steam pressure, some of the joints in the boiler...

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Joints in the boiler room piping leaked badly, and there is every reason to believe that the entire piping system has plenty of leaky joints as the piping and covering is badly deteriorated.

A system of this design should operate under a small pressure, 1 to 2 lbs., for good results; but it is not possible under existing conditions to do this.

Generally the radiation is 25% low, and in some individual rooms, the radiation is as much as 50% low, without taking into consideration the condition of the windows. In this connection the Boys' Recreation Room has 140 sq. ft. of radiation, where 226 sq. ft. is required. This is 60% low. The Girls' Recreation Room has 136 sq. ft. where 235 sq. ft. is required. This is 26% low. Varying discrepancies were noted throughout the building.

By calculation, the Basement is about 23% low, and with the radiators located at the ceiling, larger ones should have been installed to compensate for stratification of heat at the ceiling.

Many of the visible leaks over the windows, which were thought to be caused by structural faults, can be laid to pipe connections.

The Ventilating System exists in name only. It was laid out for gravity operation with heating coils placed in the air stream to induce circulation. This system is totally inadequate, and the design is quite obsolete. The system is not used now. The fresh air registers are incorrectly located, and the same can be said for the exhaust registers. The duct work appears to be fairly substantial, and is in relatively good condition. This system could be mechanized at comparatively reasonable cost and put into satisfactory operation. It is badly needed.

The Plumbing System does not present a serious problem. While blockages have occurred, we would hesitate to blame the system. Some lines should be thoroughly cleaned periodically, and some checking should be done on the use of the fixtures in the Pupils' Bathrooms. Some of the leaks and blockages could be attributed to careless use of fixtures. Some faucets need replacing, and all exposed traps should be cleaned.

No complaints were made of any shortage of hot water, but the hot water faucets should be kept in better working order.

Some structural observations were made and the following points are raised. Nearly all the windows are badly in need of repairs. The frames themselves seem to be in fairly good condition but the sash in nearly all cases is so loose that it would be hard or impossible to put into a satisfactory condition. The meeting rails do not fit together, the stops are in many cases as much as \( \frac{1}{2} \) to \( \frac{5}{8} \) away from where they should be. Most windows, in addition to having double hung sash, have inside opening casements acting as dorm sash. These casements are very poorly fitted and the fastening devices are in a poor state of repair.

Much heat is lost from this window condition and repairs are imperative...
All leaks cannot be laid to the heating or plumbing system. The roof is in bad shape. Asbestos cement shingles laid diagonally on sheathing strips have become loose and have been displaced in different areas. Looking up from inside the roof space, one can see a great number of holes all over, giving the appearance of a sieve. The galvanized iron flashing and ridge has rotted in many places and the galvanized eaves troughing is broken away and is in generally poor condition.

General Recommendations

It was pointed out by the Principal, that there is a possibility of installing laundry machinery at this school. If so, high pressure steam will be required and a new boiler would be necessary. One high pressure steam steel portable type boiler could be made to handle all the services and is therefore recommended. A return pump would be needed also.

The ventilating system should be remodeled and put into operation.

All windows, with one or two exceptions, should have extensive repairs.

It is felt also that a new roof should be laid.

Cracks in the mortar joints and brickwork should be repaired.

Plumbing and drainage lines should be cleaned, and all leaking faucets repaired or replaced as may be found necessary.

All steam mains from the boiler room should be made tight throughout, and every radiator valve replaced. Those radiators in public spaces, dormitories, recreation rooms and classrooms should be fitted with low shield valves. Additional radiation should be located in those rooms which are under heated. All radiator air vents should be replaced and the present tappings plugged and new tappings made to receive vents.

If new laundry equipment is to be provided for the school in the near future, it is recommended that the existing low pressure heating boiler be replaced by a new steel portable type high pressure steam boiler having capacity to provide for all services requiring steam. The estimated cost of this installation plus repairs to the mechanical services would be roughly $5,000.00.

If new laundry equipment is not to be provided, it is felt that the existing heating boiler could be made to serve the heating and ventilating requirements for several years yet, provided it is thoroughly overhauled. An approximate saving of $2,000.00 might be effected.

A number of important repairs to the building are vitally necessary and it is recommended that at least 48 windows be repaired, the roof replaced, and new flashing and eaves' troughing provided. The estimated cost of structural repairs, apart from work on the mechanical services, would be approximately $5,500.00.

In view of the...
In view of the complicated nature of the mechanical repairs considered necessary, it is unlikely that a contractor would submit a lump sum quotation. It is felt, therefore, that if work is approved and authorized, it should be carried out under Mr. Gow's supervision, from data and instructions previously in this office, and that Mr. Gow should be authorized to arrange for purchasing materials and obtaining the services of skilled tradesmen, to the best advantage locally. An inspection by an officer from Ottawa would be required before final payment was made.

T.S. Miller
Chief Engineer

Dear Mr. Phelan;

This happens to be Sunday. It is not the day we usually choose for writing business letters but I trust it may be excused under the circumstances.

It is pouring rain outside, the third big rain thus far in what looks to be the beginning of the Autumn wet spell. Our present distress lies not in what is happening out of doors but in the fact that the rain on each occasion comes through our perforated roof. At present we have five pails on the steps to catch the drip that has leaked through two stories to the main floor level. You can hear the drip into the pails half way through the building.

This could be laughed at providing one was in an old barn where there was nothing to take hurt. One could always shift one's position to a dry spot somewhere. When this happens in this fine building I do not think of myself or the comfort of others, I think rather of the destruction that rain creates with the walls, the floors and with the insulation in the ceilings.

Looking back over correspondence dated ten or more years ago our roof over the school residence was giving plenty of trouble. It has been a source of grief ever since. Mr. Weite our local Agent and Mr. Hamilton the Superintendent I feel sure would confirm this statement. The Engineers that were here two months ago reported the need for a new roof.

The present roof is old and worn through. The color has faded and departed with its usefulness. The time has come for a complete new covering before the sheeting and rafters underneath rot with the wet. I fear the effect of rain water getting into the chemical insulation between the studding that supports the top floor ceiling.

Whatever is decided upon with reference to this roof should be done at once before the real wet spell and before cold weather makes it slippery and cold and dangerous for men to work at such a height on a steep roof. Trusting for the sake of the interior of the building action will be taken immediately. I remain,

Yours sincerely,

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Structural Repairs to Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

Following our memorandum to you of September 5th last and your notation thereon of 6/9/48 in regard to the above, we forwarded to Mr. D.B. Gow at Winnipeg, specifications of the repair work required to be done and also instructed him to arrange for carrying out such work by day labour to the best advantage locally. Precedence was to be given to the roof repairs and expenditures were not to exceed the amount of $3,500.00 provided by Indian Affairs.

In a letter dated September 26th Mr. Gow stated that he, in company with Mr. W.H. Wallace, Engineer of his staff, and a contractor of Portage la Prairie inspected the School and noted the various repairs required. Mr. Gow stated that whereas we had contemplated stripping off the existing hexagonal roof shingles and resurfacing with new rectangular asbestos cement, or asphalt shingles, he finds that (a) new asbestos shingles are at present unobtainable; (b) the roof boarding and tar paper are defective, and (c) the present shingles are very largely in good condition and could be reused along with an additional quantity of the same pattern, which he has hopes of obtaining, to make a first class roofing job.

He also stated that it would not be possible to carry out the roof repairs by day labour as he could not obtain the proper labour, or materials, and that no local firms are in a position to carry out the work.

Regarding the repairs to leaky windows, which we had specified to be refitted with new stops and brickmoulds, etc., Mr. Webb states:

"The matter of repairs to windows has been reviewed and it is now intended to utilize metal weatherstrip. Winnipeg firms are being requested to examine the windows and to quote prices covering such work".

Under date of October 17th, Mr. Gow advised that he had arranged with the Peace Weatherstrip Supply Company, of Winnipeg, to install weatherstripping at a cost of $440.00.

We have now received a further letter from Mr. Gow, dated October 26th, with which he forwarded a tender from the Canadian Rogers Sheet Metal and Roofing Limited, of Winnipeg, Encls. for repairs to the School roofs, copies of which we are transmitting for your information and that of the Indian Affairs Branch.

(over)

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6274, file 583-5, part 8)
In his covering letter Mr. Gow states:

"We have endeavoured to secure estimate from other firms but have failed to interest any of them in giving us quotations."

You will note that the tender received is for roofing repairs only and that it includes the removal and relaying of the present shingles with renewals, as necessary.

The amount of $5,500.00 for this work is, in our opinion, high but Mr. Gow has been unable to obtain any other tenders and the matter of repairing the School roofs is an urgent necessity for the preservation of the building, as well as for the reasonable comfort of the occupants.

It is probable that the other structural work consisting of mastic caulking to the brickwork and window frames, the insulation of ceilings and carpentry work, which is required to complete the weatherproofing of the School building will, under present conditions, involve an additional cost of at least $1,500.00 but this work, although necessary, is not as urgently needed as the first named repairs, and it might be held over until the summer of 1947.

It is suggested, therefore, that the Indian Affairs Branch be asked whether, under the circumstances, an additional amount of $2,500.00 could be provided to make up a total of $8,000.00 permitting the roofing repairs and weatherstripping to be carried out this year.

In view of the lateness of the season, it is requested that an early decision be made in the matter of acceptance of the enclosed tender, and we will await your instructions in regard thereto.

We have received advice from Mr. Gow that the amount of $1,000. allotted by Indian Affairs for one phase of the work required on the heating system will also likely be exceeded, but as the tender submitted required clarification, we have asked Mr. Gow to advise us further before we report on that division of the work.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Revisions and Additions to Heating System, Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

Further to our memorandum of October 31st, 1946, in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

Mr. Gow has informed us that no plumbing and heating firms in Portage la Prairie were interested in the above work and refused to quote. However, he contacted a Winnipeg firm, Messrs. Randall and Company, who were highly recommended to him, and they have offered to do the work outlined in our specification for the sum of $2,704.00.

In view of the transportation of workmen and materials, and the somewhat complicated nature of the work, this price does not seem unreasonable. It is noted that Indian Affairs allotted $1,000.00 for this phase of the work, a sum which we felt was inadequate, but which we did not feel inclined, at the time to criticise, until estimates had been received from Mr. Gow.

In the strictest sense, no actual emergency has arisen through existing inconsistencies in the heating system, but it is again pointed out that the amount of radiation is generally 25% low and in some rooms as much as 50% low, which, in addition to causing discomfort, is a potential hazard to the health of the occupants.

After thoroughly considering the requirements, it is our opinion that if any part of this phase of the work is omitted the results will be questionable. We, therefore,
recommend that Indian Affairs be asked to provide the sum mentioned and authorize acceptance of the Randall tender at once, if the School is to receive any benefit from the work this winter.

(Sgd.) T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,

Department of Mines and Resources,

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Portage La Prairie Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

In connection with the structural repairs and alterations to the heating system at the above, you are advised as follows:

Mr. Gow has informed us that the Canadian Rogers Sheet Metal and Roofing Ltd., are prepared to carry out work in their quotation at a price of $6,500.00. This includes repairs to the roof only, and omits other repairs to the interior of the building, estimated to cost in the neighborhood of $1,500. I beg to attach hereto a letter received from Mr Jones, Principal, Portage la Prairie Residential School, in which he asks for an approximate sum of $275.00 for the raising of the floor in the poultry house and a concrete floor in the tractor shed and garage. It is the Principal's intention to again raise poultry and he has at present 150 chicks. This sideline was discontinued by his predecessor. This spring the floor of the poultry house was flooded. The floor is below ground level, with a cement wall approximately 18 inches. This filled in completely with water in the early spring. Most of this water was run-off from the yard. I would recommend that the floor be built up level with the outside, at a cost mentioned above.

The Principal asked for three oil burner units for the cookstove. He claims that wood fuel is becoming too expensive. He is obtaining prices on these units and they will be submitted to the Department at a later date. On inquiry regarding these units for cooking purposes, I am informed that at present they are not satisfactory.

He also wishes a built-in refrigerator. At present he has two units, which he claims are not large enough for the purpose required. This is probably true as he now has an ample supply of milk and will find it difficult to keep during the summer months. A price on building this refrigerator will be obtained and later forwarded to the Department.

Fire equipment was carefully checked. Was informed that fire-drill is carried out. A number of the soda extinguishers were requiring refilling and a requisition will be forwarded to the Department for material in the course of a few days.

The fire-escape platform is too small. In the event
of a fire in the building, the platform would likely be overcrowded and accidents might occur. I would suggest that the platform be extended fifteen to twenty feet along the side of the building. This job should be looked into by an engineer. This matter was taken up with Mr. Gow in Winnipeg, but instructions would have to come from the Department, before he would attend to the matter.

At the present time gasoline for the tractor is being stored in a shed between the buildings. I informed the Principal that this is strictly against all fire prevention regulations. The building is not even tin lined. I suggested that he obtain costs on a 500 gal. tank and distributor. The tank should be underground. Costs of this will also be forwarded, as soon as received.

My understanding is, that the school roof, painting and a change in the electric wiring will be carried out this summer.

J. Waite,

Dear Mr. Waite:

Will you give consideration to the following suggestions re improvements to the equipment of this school.

Installation of 500 gallon storage tank -
At present our gasoline is stored in barrels in a wood shed. This I consider a fire hazard. The underground tank with pump will be the safest way to store gasoline. I will secure prices later and submit them to you.

Oil Burners for kitchen range -
Our range has three fire boxes and is fitted as a wood burner. It consumes large quantities of wood and the price of cord wood at the present time is very high. I am having to pay $8.50 a cord for slabs. Oil burners would be very much more economical. These oil burners burn distillate which is not explosive unless heated to a very high temperature. This type of burner has been installed in many households and would be quite safe to install in our range. The approximate price for the three fireboxes would be about $450.00. I will secure definite prices later.

Walk-in Refrigerator -
At present we do not have adequate refrigeration for the proper care of our perishable foodstuffs. We have the ideal location for a walk-in refrigerator and I would like to discuss this question with your engineers when they next visit the school.
Sewage connection to Scullery -
In the scullery where the children's dishes are washed there is no sewage connection. The waste water has to be carried out and poured down the drain in the kitchen. This method involves a lot of extra labour and is far from satisfactory in every way. Could we have a large sanitary sink installed and connected with the drain? The present equipment in use is far from adequate.

Repairs to steps at Boys' Entrance -
Some cement work is necessary here which could be done at a cost of approximately $30.00.

Repairs to Maple Flooring -
There are many places in the school where the maple flooring is worn through. To patch up these places we shall require about 350 sq. feet of maple flooring. I am well aware that this type of flooring is difficult to obtain at the present time.

Painting in Main Building -
The interior and exterior of the two balconies on the west side of the building should be painted.

Fire Extinguishers -
Two new fire extinguishers, Gardene, made by Pyrene Mfg. Co., 91 East Don Roadway, Toronto.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones

MEMORANDUM

Re: Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

Some time ago, the Director of Indian Affairs asked us for information in regard to absolutely essential structural repair work at the above school about which there had been considerable correspondence last year.

Mr. Hoey also stated that Indian Agent Waite had suggested certain changes to the fire escape landings at the school and it was proposed that we ask Mr. D.H. Gow, District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water and Power Bureau at Winnipeg, to investigate and submit an estimate of the cost of carrying out the Agent's suggestion.

On October 16th last, we wrote to Mr. Gow and have now received a long letter in reply, which may be summed up as follows:

Mr. Gow states that the situation in regard to materials and labour for structural repair work at the school is now becoming somewhat easier, and it may be possible to interest firms in submitting tenders in 1948 in the carrying out of such work.

Regarding Indian Agent Waite's suggestion for changes to the landing of the exterior fire escapes from the upper floors, Mr. Gow states that an examination was recently made and the situation was discussed with Mr. Jones, School Principal, and the Indian Agent. He advised that the escapes are of standard steel construction and that the platforms appear to be sufficiently large for their purpose. Pole fire escapes from the two top floor rear dormitories running through enclosed porches have been replaced by wooden staircases as alternative emergency exits.

Mr. Gow criticizes these exits as, being within enclosed porches, they provide in themselves a considerable fire hazard. He states that the provision of slide exits directly from the Senior Boys and Senior Girls Dormitories to the ground should receive consideration rather than any alterations in connection with the two rear staircases.

We are asking Mr. Gow to submit a definite recommendation covering the emergency escape requirements at the school together with an estimate of cost of carrying out the same, and as soon as we have received such information from him, we will transmit it to you for Indian Affairs.

Chief Engineer.

Dear Mr. Waite,

There are several repair items that should receive immediate attention to put our equipment in good shape.

First, The water works are wanting to put in a meter for the water we are using in the barn. Up to the present we have been paying a flat rate of $2.75 per month. From the main pipe we have a galvanised pipe which I installed in 1936; this pipe has rusted in places and the City Engineer would not venture to attach meter to this; if this pipe should break it would flood the root cellar and destroy all our stored vegetables; the engineer recommends that we put a lead pipe from the main and shut off at that point to prevent flooding if at any time a pipe should break. May I have authority to have the city do this work.

Second, The wiring in the chicken house is in very poor shape and dangerous, the pipes are rusted. The present lead-in will have to be replaced by a new lead from the barn connection. The cost will not exceed $65.00.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.,

We are in receipt of your voucher No. S102 in favour of the Beaver Lumber Company for $112.40 covering the cost of lumber purchased for repairs to the chicken house at the Portage la Prairie Residential School.

In a letter dated November 26th from the Principal which you forwarded under cover of your letter of December 18, 1947, he stated in part as follows:

"Second, the wiring in the chicken house is in very poor shape and dangerous, the pipes are rusted. The present lead-in will have to be replaced by a new lead from the barn connection. The cost will not exceed $65.00."

In official letter of January 5, 1948, we authorized an expenditure of $65.00 for making the necessary repairs to the chicken house. The account accompanying your voucher covers the cost of lumber and the total is $112.40, while an expenditure of only $65.00 was authorized. As you can realize it is impossible for us to control our appropriation if expenditures are made that are greatly in excess of the amount authorized. Please let me have an explanation of the matter.

Re: Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

You are advised that we are in receipt of a letter from Mr. Gow under date of March 25th, 1948, in which he states that the Principal at the above school has brought to his attention the advisability of replacing the present heating boiler.

When our Mr. Hargreaves visited this school in January, 1946, for the purpose of inspecting the heating system, the Principal advised him that he expected to be supplied with laundry machines in the near future.

Since nothing definite was known at that time, with reference to the proposed installation of laundry machinery, it was felt that the present heating boiler could be repaired and made to serve for a few years; and when a decision was made with reference to the laundry equipment, a new boiler plant could be more intelligently selected.

As a result of our engineer's inspection, general revisions to the heating system have been carried out, including repairs to the existing heating boiler. This boiler is nearing the end of its usefulness, and it is felt that the Principal's request for a new unit is not unreasonable.

However before an estimate of the cost of the replacement can be furnished, it will be necessary for Indian Affairs to decide, whether or not laundry equipment is to be provided for the school.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I would like to replace the 34 single beds we have in the school with 17 double deck beds (army beds) and mattresses. We find the double deck beds have a great advantage over the single beds as we have more floor space thus making it easier to keep the dormitories clean. The dormitories are very high about 14 feet. With double deck beds we can space the beds and avoid direct draughts from the windows.

I wrote to the Department on June 6th to say that our already leaking roof had been further damaged by the cyclone of that day. The repairing of this roof has been pending for some time. The holiday season is the time to get this done. Will you urge upon the Department the necessity of immediate action in this regard. I understand that the firm of Alexander Murray of Winnipeg are experts on repairing roofs.

Attention Mr. Hamilton,

Dear Sir:

After discussing the roof of the Indian School at Portage la Prairie with your Mr. Davis, he asked me to drop you a line explaining the condition of the roof and suggestions as to its repair.

On examining this roof and checking the shingles that are now existing I would say that the proper thing to do with this job would be to remove all existing roofing and apply a 210 lb. weight asphalt shingle with 1 ply of Asphalt Felt under. In the valleys we would use a Slate Surface Roofing, 2 plys full 36" wide re-inforced with felt and make sure of no leaks. On the ridges we will put what is known as Boston Hip Capping.

For this work we quote you a lump sum of $2450.00.

We will be able to proceed with this work at approximately any given time. Materials we propose to use under these figures will be a Canadian Johns-Manville Thick Butt Shingle.

I made temporary repairs to this roof last week and I hope it held out under the last rain.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr Doucet,

I am forwarding under separate cover plans for the erection of clothing lockers for both girls and boys. These lockers are to be placed in the playrooms for the convenience of the pupils to store their extra clothing and keep the playrooms tidy.

Bill of material is attached.

Col. Neary was here during my absence and suggested the making of new cupboards.

We will do the work in our Manual Training Department.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones

"A ventilating system is in place but is practically inoperative due to the heating coils having been disconnected and the fresh air openings to the heating coil having been blocked up. I am forwarding herewith a copy of letter received from Mr. F. M. Brickenden, Supervising Engineer, Prairie Region, and addressed to Dr. W. J. Wood. I might state that I have had no complaints from Portage la Prairie regarding this sewage disposal.

I note that he recommends that the sewage disposal from the septic tank enter Crescent Lake rather than the Assiniboine River. As far as I am aware, all the sewage from Portage la Prairie enters the Assiniboine River - and I fail to see how the sewage system affects the health of the Indian children. I also feel that if we have no complaints from the town of Portage la Prairie, we should not go to the expense of putting in a new sewage system. However, I would request that you take the matter up with Mr. Gow, as I understand he is thoroughly familiar with this sewage system, as they did some work on it in 1941 - which, apparently, was satisfactory to all concerned.

Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Dear Dr. Wood:

Re: Sewage Disposal
Indian Residential school
Portage la Prairie

In reference to the above subject may I review what has been done.

We received copies of Dr. Manly's letters to you regarding the complaints of this sewage disposal plant. Two calls have been made previously by myself and letters have been sent out in regard to this matter. It was brought out in conversation with Dr. Manly that the effluent from these septic tanks enter Crescent Lake rather than the Assiniboine River.

On Saturday morning, July 9th, along with Mr. McEwan of Dr. Manly's office, a visit was made to this school where we contacted the principal and examined the situation together. We found that there are two lines from the school, one discharging the kitchen wastes, the other discharging from a septic tank and services the basins and toilets. No stable services come this way. Apparently these septic tanks are unrecorded at Ottawa (Mines and Resources) as far as blueprints are concerned. It was also noticed that no breathers were apparent although on the present lakeside of the school there were two manholes.

It seems to be best for brevity that this matter be reduced to the form of recommendations. It is recommended that a single two cell septic tank be erected on the townside of the school between 75' and 100' away from the nearest school corner. This tank would receive all the liquid wastes from the school except the stable portion.
Proceeding the line from the kitchens there would be a grease trap. This septic tank could be vented on the fence line so that it would not be unsightly and the effluent from this could be chlorinated and passed through a gravel filled concrete channel to discharge into the lake as one line. There should be a gravel filled open topped reinforced concrete "U", the gravel to be pea sized to 2" with no fines. This would act as an aerator and the chlorination would be of considerable assistance in reducing smell and odors. The effluent into the lake might easily be placed in water at a depth exceeding 36". The frost penetration is at least 5'.

I hope that our remarks here will be of value to you. With best wishes, I remain,

Yours very truly,

F. M. Brickenden,
Supervising Engineer,
Prairie Region.
Ottawa, July 22nd, 1949.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Sewage Disposal,
Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

Referring to the memorandum from Indian Affairs, dated July 22, 1949, we have only now received the following, under date of September 23rd, from Mr. Gow in reply to our letter of July 28th:

"This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 28 with respect to the above subject.

"We are enclosing copy of a letter forwarded to Dr. W. J. Wood, Regional Superintendent, Indian Health Services, 52 Dominion Public Building, Winnipeg, under date of July 29, 1949, which points out the viewpoint of this office with respect to complaints originating through Dr. Manly of Portage la Prairie. These complaints have to do with discharge of effluent from septic tank into Crescent Lake near Portage la Prairie.

"In 1941, when this office carried out certain works with respect to the sewage disposal system at this school, the matter was gone into very thoroughly with the Parks Board of the Town of Portage la Prairie and it was agreed at that time that the work to be undertaken was all that could reasonably be expected of the Indian Affairs Branch. We do not believe that any further work is necessary at this time but the writer will arrange for an engineer to call at the Institution in the near future to see the conditions that now exist and to report upon the same."

Duplicate copies of the letter of July 29th from Mr. Gow to Dr. Wood are attached herewith.

You will note Mr. Gow's remarks with regard to the cleaning out of septic tanks, and that a report on the conditions which now exist will be forwarded in due course.

Chief, Engineering & Construction Division.

Attach.

R. A. Gibson,
Director,

Department of Mines & Resources,

532 Dominion Public Bldg.,
WINNIPEG, July 29th, 1949.

W.J. Wood, M.D.,
Regional Superintendent,
Indian Health Services,
522 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Re: Sewage Disposal System,
Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie.

We have for attention your letter of July 15th, enclosing report from Mr. F.M. Brickenden, Supervising Engineer, Department of National Health and Welfare. The remarks and suggestions of Mr. Brickenden have been noted.

In 1941, this office with the approval of Indian Affairs Branch spent approximately $2,000.00 on improvements to the sewage disposal system of this School following complaints from the Parks Board of Portage la Prairie about odors and so forth. The work involved separation of kitchen and laundry wastes from the sewage in the building, the construction of new drains, manholes and septic tank. Plans covering construction details of this work are available in the Indian Office at Portage la Prairie, at Ottawa and in this office. The manholes have air vents and are sufficiently removed from the school as to be inoffensive. The sewage disposal system at this school is not considered to be detrimental to the health of the school inmates; it satisfies the requirements of the Provincial Health Officials and while the drainage from the school and the effluent from the septic tank is discharged directly into Crescent Lake, this body of water is not used for domestic water supply or bathing and receives much surface pollution as well as being connected with discharge pipes from the Portage la Prairie Sewage System.

The school is over a mile from the town limits and the trunk line of the town sewage system is inadequate to serve the nearest four intervening blocks of the town without resorting to pumping and so no connection with the municipal system is possible. It is not possible to install any sewage disposal system at this school that will not have some offensive odors and we do not believe that the proposals suggested by Mr. Brickenden will materially improve the situation or prevent the complaints being received from time to time from the Parks Board of Portage la Prairie. At the time of construction, the Indian Affairs Branch were informed that catch basins and septic tank should be cleaned out at least yearly. Undoubtedly this advice has not been followed and consequently the system is not working to best advantage. We have again drawn to the attention of Mr. Davis the necessity of advising operators of all Indian Schools where such disposal systems are in use that septic tanks, catch basins and so forth must be regularly cleaned out.

Yours truly,

D. B. Gow,
District Engineer.

THE POTATO PEELER

This Potato Peeler is manufactured in two sizes, 15 and 25 lbs. capacity each. They are made of cast aluminum, buffed, and are of pleasing appearance.

The top cover is rounded and hollowed out on the inside and provided with water connections. The bowl and the rotating platen are lined with the well known "Hardt abrasive patented liner". The bowl is equipped with a 2 in. standard pipe drain.

The platen is mounted on a vertical shaft with a bronze lined guide and lubricated with a grease cup. The lower end of the shaft is mounted on a ball thrust bearing.

Under the bowl a cross shaft drives the platen through a set of mitre gears which are well lapped on their working centres. Adjacent to the horizontal shaft bearing, which is supported on a shelf, is the switch-box, waterproof and grounded. The peeler is operated by a ¼ H.P. motor totally enclosed and splash proof, equipped with a "V" belt drive and pulleys. This motor can be seen mounted below on a pivoted support which permits belt tension adjustment. The peeler is easily operated; it is merely filled through the top, the water turned on, and the motor started. The platen rotates and tumbles the potatoes. When they come in contact with the abrasive liners they are peeled. The complete cycle takes about 2 minutes. The peeler then is emptied simply by opening the side door.

To clean the peeler simply remove the rounded top and pull the platen out. This machine must be thoroughly cleaned every day to prevent oxidization of the liners.

MEMORANDUM

December 2nd, 1949.

R. A. Gibson, Esq., Director,

Re: Sewage Disposal - Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

Further to our memorandum to you of September 27th last, we have now received a short report from Mr. Gow. He visited the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School on November 16th and discussed the sewage disposal situation with Dr. C.E. Manly, head of the Portage la Prairie Health Unit, and also with the Chairman of the Medical Health Unit and the Chairman of the Parks Board. He also paid a visit to the Indian School.

Mr. Gow advises that the situation at the school is not detrimental to either the inmates of the institution or the citizens of Portage la Prairie, but he intends to forward a more complete report shortly. In the meantime he is taking soil samples with the object of submitting an estimate of cost with regard to the installation of a disposal system to eliminate the complaints by the Portage la Prairie officials.

You will be advised when the more complete report is received.

Chief.
Extract from letter from W. G. Weir, M.P. for Portage-Noepawa, Man., dated December 3, 1949.

Sewage Disposal - Portage School

The general understanding I got from these memoranda was to the effect that the sewage disposal system referred to has been repaired, and was generally considered to be satisfactory so far as the school was concerned, with the only complaint remaining being the disposal of the sewage into Crescent Lake. It is understood and known that the people of Portage la Prairie were complaining about this open disposal to the Lake on the grounds that it created a disagreeable odor, and of course they were anxious to have the matter remedied.

I now find a news item in the Winnipeg Free Press, under a Portage la Prairie date-line, where it is reported "that plans were being drawn up to connect the Indian School with the City sewage system instead of having it empty into Crescent Lake as at present".

I really would like to know what is being planned in this regard so that one might have a little information as to what is taking place with respect to a Government institution in the City of Portage la Prairie. I should therefore be obliged for any additional information you may be able to procure for me.

My dear Mr. Hamilton:

With reference to Mr. School Inspector Simms' recommendation that an additional classroom be provided at Portage La Prairie Indian Residential School I enclose related materials:
(a) Memorandum to the Superintendent of Indian Education
(b) Sketches of three ways to add a classroom outside
(c) An elaboration of one of these sketches (Plan B).

I have not yet obtained the Principal's concurrence to using the boys' playroom temporarily. I am assured by Mr. Gow that the additional radiators that were recently installed in this room will make the heating nearly adequate. I do not think that it will be necessary to spend much on electrical fixtures, but the room should be re-decorated in a lighter colour. The grills should be removed from the windows. Would you consult with Mr. McLean, please, and submit an estimate of the items and costs involved?

In regard to the outside construction, no money has been voted for 1949-50 and, accordingly, there may be no way to expedite construction. I would like to have a practical builder's opinion regarding the feasibility and probable cost of Plan B. There, perhaps, are features that seem difficult. Without, therefore, committing the Department to any expenditure or promise thereof, would you invite any parties who might be interested in doing the job to study the project and make a tentative (a) bill of materials (b) labour estimate or alternatively bid on the complete job—approximately, of course.

I have not been able to discover any army or air force buildings that we could acquire and move to the grounds. You may have seen some at McDonald or other points in your travels in the area. Or at Elkhorn—but I doubt it—there may be something movable and desirable.

I regret that our respective journeyings prevented our discussing the various visits I made in your agency, but I gave Mr. Russell my views on certain things, and he in turn showed me every courtesy. It's a little early, but I take this opportunity to wish you and the staff there the compliments of the season.

Yours most sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Sewage Disposal - Portage la Prairie I.R.S., Manitoba.

Replying to the memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs, dated December 9th, on the subject of sewage disposal from the above-named Indian School, we have now received a report from Mr. Gow, dated December 19th, duplicate copies of which are attached herewith.

Mr. Gow does not appear to be convinced that the odours which are the subject of complaint, originate from the school sewage system. The local Indian Agent ought, however, to be able to report more definitely whether odours from the school system have given rise to complaint.

A further report is expected from Mr. Gow, which when received can be made the basis for a decision in regard to the work necessary to eliminate any future complaints. It should be noted that chlorination of the sewer effluent is receiving consideration. Such action would no doubt meet with the approval of the officials of the City of Portage la Prairie.

Attachs.
Re: Sewage Disposal - Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

We have for attention your letter of December 16 with reference to the above matter. We note the extract from the inquiry of Mr. W.G. Weir, M.P. for Portage-Neepawa, concerning the sewage disposal system at the school.

Our engineers visited the Portage School in late November, took some additional elevations and soil samples and examined the condition of the cistern basins, septic tank and the drainage system in the school itself. The matter of the treatment of the discharge from the septic tank and school drainage is now under consideration and has been discussed with Provincial Government Officials and local representatives of chlorinating agencies. It is hoped to forward you shortly cost data with respect to two alternative proposals for the treatment of the sewage problem. One will provide for chlorination of the effluent prior to discharge into Crescent Lake while the second will deal with the provision of a tile disposal field.

The discharge of the school sewage into the City's sewage system would be an expensive but complete solution to the problem. Unfortunately, the City of Portage la Prairie has been unable to provide water and sewer facilities to the westerly seven or eight blocks of part of its residential area and as the school is situated more than a mile west of this district, there is little prospect of any possible connecting of the school with the City's sewage system. The news-item in the "Winnipeg Free Press" under Portage la Prairie date-line, as referred to in Mr. Weir's communication, was not based upon any information originating with this office and is apparently not based upon fact. I am informed that the complaints regarding the odors from the school sewerage come mainly from residents with properties fronting on Crescent Lake and situated immediately east of the area now without water and sewers. It could be that the odors complained of originated with the hundred or more less fortunate families that lack city water and sewers and must therefore depend upon outdoor facilities.

Crescent Lake is a fairly large but shallow body of water, probably 2½ miles long and 1,000 feet wide, with neither inlet or outlet but maintained during the summer months by pumping of water from the Assiniboine River. It receives considerable surface pollution as well as some direct pollution from the Portage la Prairie Agricultural Grounds and because of its stagnant water it develops the objectionable odors associated with rotting vegetation and etc. The Indian School is located near the westerly limits of the lake, 1½ miles beyond the city limits and the writer is in full agreement with the Chairman of the Medical Health Unit and also of the Parks Board when he remarked upon the occasion of my meeting with him on November 16 last, that he thought the grounds for complaints were more imaginary than real.

This office hopes to have the report dealing with the two alternative proposals relating to the sewage disposal problem at the school completed in the near future. At the present time we are instructed to avoid any appropriation press and we are verbally advised by the City of Portage la Prairie officials that such treatment will meet with their approval and will eliminate future complaints.

(Sgd.) D.B. Gow,
District Engineer.

Memorandum

Mr. D. B. Gow

Re:- Sewage Disposal - Portage la Prairie
Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

In the present system as constructed in August, 1941, the sewage is passed through a septic tank and this effluent, together with the laundry and kitchen wastes, discharged directly to Crescent Lake. To avoid pollution of Crescent Lake with consequent disagreeable odors, the following alternative schemes are suggested:

1. Chlorination of all effluent before discharging to lake.
2. Construction of Disposal Bed to receive all effluents.

1. CHLORINATION SCHEME

Proposed Apparatus and Housing:

It is proposed to install a small chlorinating system on the 6" pipe line, about 40 feet from outlet of septic tank, at the junction of laundry and kitchen wastes with the main sewage line. The type of chlorinator most suitable is a "Manual Direct Feed Chlorinator Control - Orifice type chlorinator". This chlorinator to be housed in a building 6' x 9' with 7' ceiling, built over a 3' x 3' well. The building would be thoroughly insulated with provision of heating unit for use during severe cold weather in order that the room temperature may be maintained to give the necessary pressure to operate the flow of chlorine. The well to be carried down to a depth of 10 ft. below ground level, giving a minimum depth of 4½ ft. below incoming pipes. It would always be full of liquid at this depth and would constitute the contact chamber (capacity 250 gals.) for the application of chlorine.

Chlorine Requirement:

A daily amount of 3,000 gals. of liquid to be treated has been arrived at from the maximum monthly water consumption. However, the rate of flow during the 24-hour period will vary considerably. An assumed steady chlorine treatment of about 25 p.p.m. to the daily effluent of 3,000 gals. is considered satisfactory, but there is no doubt that at times the contents of the contact chamber would be over chlorinated and possibly during periods of high discharge it might not be sufficient considering periods of time of contact. However, the rate of flow of chlorine can be regulated by the manual control during periods of high and low discharge. The suggested treatment of 25 p.p.m. to 3,000 gals. per 24-hour period, would require about one pound of chlorine daily.

Electric Power:

A 110 volt supply for necessary lighting of building and to electrically heat the diffuser element of the chlorinator if required.

Advantages of this type of chlorinator:

1. No auxiliary water line is required, as in the case of hypochlorinators,
2. Heating requirements at a minimum,
3. Minimum supervision - Only regulation of chlorine control valve.
