2. DISPOSAL BED SCHEME

The existing septic tank is not provided with a siphon chamber and due to the elevation of the present effluent being nearly 6 feet below ground, it is not possible to conform to the usual practice of syphoning to the disposal bed. It is proposed to construct an additional chamber at the end of the septic tank to be called the "Effluent Chamber", where the effluent from the septic tank and the laundry and kitchen will be collected and this raised to the tile in disposal bed by means of pumping. The size of "Effluent Chamber" and "Disposal Bed" have been made on the basis of the average monthly water consumption at the school, being 12,000 c.c.ft. (97,500 gals.) and from this the daily average of 450 c.c.ft. (3,380 gals.) has been considered.

Effluent Chamber

Concrete construction 8 ft. wide and 10 ft. long and 6 ft. deep. Elevation of floor to be 90.0 giving a liquid depth of 3 ft. (240 cc.ft. = 1,500 gal. capacity) at time of pump operation under float control. Platform to be constructed above maximum liquid level for the erection of pump. Accessibility to this chamber to be provided by manhole (3' x 3') from ground above. The present main sewage line to Crescent Lake to be connected to an overflow pipe from chamber in event of pump failure at any time, and this means of taking care of the effluent could be used at any time when occasion demands the rehabilitating of the disposal bed.
Disposal Bed:

Location of the bed under law in front of school or in the girls' playground is considered satisfactory as regards soil conditions which were found to be 18" clay loam over 36" of silty yellow clay to fine or medium sand. The 6" glass distributor pipe with 4" tile laterals running at right angles from it to be laid at a depth of 2 feet and the 4" tile laid open joints at the base level in specially prepared trenches 2 ft. wide with a 6" deep gravel base. The size of the proposed disposal bed is 13,500 sq. ft., with 3,150 lin.ft. of 4" tile in the bed. The capacity of the Effluent Chamber being 1500 gals. will give approximately a twice daily loading of disposal bed.

Grease Trap:

A grease trap to be provided in the laundry and kitchen waste line before it enters the "Effluent Chamber".

WINNIPEG, January 19, 1950.

Re: Sewage Disposal - Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

As promised in our letter of December 19 last, we are forwarding a memorandum by Mr. W.H. Wallace of this staff outlining two alternative methods of treating the sewage at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. The memorandum outlines the details of the two methods suggested and gives estimated costs for both proposals. The memorandum is accompanied by two plans of the school grounds on which are outlined the location of the proposed new work. Plans showing construction details are in course of preparation and can be brought to completion for whatever method of disposal is decided upon. The memorandum and plans are being forwarded in duplicate.

It might be pointed out that both methods of treatment outlined are open to criticism. School authorities have not been consulted with respect to the location of the disposal bed and will doubtless look with disfavour upon the idea of their attractive lawn and flower beds being torn up and will also dislike the idea of losing the girls' playground which is an alternative location for the tile bed. On the other hand, the chlorination of the effluent presents problems. There is no steady use of water in the school and since the flow of chlorine gas remains steady, there is bound to be over and under chlorination at times. Furthermore, chlorination does not do away with Crescent Lake being the recipient of the chlorinated effluent and this fact alone will probably be future grounds for complaint, for regardless of whatever method of disposal is proceeded with the disagreeable odors arising from the waters of Crescent Lake in warm weather will continue since the stagnant water of this lake lends itself readily to such a situation.

'sgd' D.B. Gow,
District Engineer.

Enclos.

Mr. C.Victor F. Weir,
Chief,
Engineering and Construction Division,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
Further to our memorandum of December 27th, and in response to the request of the Director of Indian Affairs under date of December 9th, 1950, we are forwarding herewith one copy of a report by Mr. Wallace, accompanied by two copies of the covering letter from Mr. Gow.

The attached report dated January 19th by Mr. Wallace deals with two alternative schemes for dealing with sewage effluent. They are as follows:

Scheme (1) provides for chlorination of the effluent before it is deposited in Crescent Lake, at an estimated cost of $3,530 for labour and materials. This proposal will require maintenance which is estimated to cost $125 per year. While this scheme may seem to be a satisfactory method of eliminating odours from the sewage there is always the possibility that repairs might be required to the chlorinator and in view of the fact that there is no steady use of water in the school and the flow of chlorine gas remains steady there is bound to be over and under chlorination at times. There is also the possibility of shut downs for repairs. So long as sewage is turned into Crescent Lake from the school there will be grounds for complaint.

Scheme (2) provides for the construction of a tiled disposal bed in the school grounds and owing to the elevations which exist pumping of the sewage effluent will be necessary. The estimated cost of this scheme is $3,550 for labour and materials. It is proposed to leave the present sewer pipe to Crescent Lake as an alternative means of disposal when repairs are being made to the pump and the disposal bed. The soil is not particularly suited to this type of disposal and an artificial gravel bed will have to be laid. The plans provide for construction of this disposal bed on the lawn immediately in front of the school, with an alternative location on the girls' playground.

In Mr. Gow's report of December 19th, copies of which were forwarded to you on December 27th, you will note that he states:

"The discharge of the school sewage into the city's sewage system would be an expensive but a complete solution of the problem. Unfortunately, the city of Portage la Prairie has been unable to provide water and sewage facilities to the westerly seven or eight blocks of part of the residential area and as the school is situated more than a mile west of this district there is little prospect of any possible connecting of the school with the city sewage system." In the same report Mr. Gow states that "the Indian School is located near the westerly limits of the lake 1-1/2 miles beyond the city limits and the writer is in full agreement with the Chairman of the Medical Health Unit and also of the Parks Department when he remarked on the occasion of my meeting with him on November 16 last that he thought the grounds..."
for complaints were more imaginary than real."

You will note from the last paragraph of Mr. Gow's letter that both the above methods of treatment are open to criticism. In the first place the school authorities have not been consulted with regard to the location of the disposal bed, and in all probability will not be in favour of the idea of tearing up their lawn and flower beds or the girls' playground, which is the alternative location. We believe that the school authorities should be consulted before additional work is done on this scheme. Furthermore, if the disposal bed scheme is adopted there is bound to be some pollution of the lake during periods when the disposal bed has to be rehabilitated.

In view of the fact that neither of the proposals submitted by Mr. Wallace is entirely satisfactory and the ultimate solution to the problem would be discharging the affluent into the river, we are again referring to Mr. Gow to find out from him what length of sewer would have to be constructed from the school to the river and also if there are any particular difficulties to such a scheme. On receipt of Mr. Gow's further report we will advise further.

Atteh.

Chief.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

In order to provide an additional classroom for the above school, we purchased from War Assets Corporation, a former army building located at the T.C.A. Airport at St. James near Winnipeg, Manitoba. The building is approximately 99 ft. in length, and Superintendent Davis has obtained a quotation of $3,000.00 to move the building to Portage la Prairie, from R. Litz & Sons, 277 McPhillips Street, Winnipeg.

This firm recommend that the building be cut in two halves, and temporary end walls be built at both the openings created by the cutting of the building in order to prevent the side walls from going out of shape in transit. They will also look after obtaining permits for moving the building, and will place it on the site selected by our officials at Portage la Prairie.

This firm can move the building immediately, and it is pointed out that this a most opportune time to move it, because the roads are firmly frozen and there is lighter traffic on the highway at this period of the year.

Our Building Supervisor, Mr. M. Krawchuk, who is attached to our Winnipeg office, considers that the firm mentioned above are in a position to handle the work in a competent manner. Regional Supervisor Davis recommends that they be employed as they promise to move the building at once. Funds for the moving are available in the current year's appropriation.
Therefore, I recommend for the Minister's approval, that we accept the tender of R. Litz & Sons to move the building mentioned above from its present location to the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, at a cost of $3,000.00.

Litz & Sons of Winnipeg, for the sum of $3,000.00. This firm will move the building by cutting it in two and placing it close together, so it can be connected again at Portage la Prairie. This building is about a foot wider than the bridges, therefore, it will be necessary to raise the building high enough on the trucks to go over the bridges. After this building has been moved, it will be necessary, the first thing in the Spring - to clean up the lot where the building stood, as per the Purchase contract. This could be done by calling for extra prices. I imagine the cost would be around $300.00, at least, as there is a cement floor to move and some filling in to do.

Boland Bros. Limited, of Winnipeg, have quoted a price of $3,250.00, but they will only take this building down and move it in sections - then put it up again at Portage la Prairie.

I have had Mr. M. Krawchuk, our Building Supervisor, check the building, and he recommends that the building should not be taken down and moved in sections - but that it be moved in two pieces. Mr. Krawchuk advises that the building would
never be as substantial and would take a lot of extra repairs to put it back in shape, if moved in sections.

I would recommend that R. Litz & Sons be given the contract to move this building, and I am forwarding in this connection, a letter from them stating that they will have the work completed for the 31st of March.

If you would wire me instructions, I will immediately get in touch with the firm submitting the successful tender, and have the work started at once.

R.-S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

work would be done at once and accounts in Ottawa by April 1st.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

In order to provide an additional classroom for the above school, we purchased from War Assets Corporation, a former army building located at the T.C.A. Airport at St. James near Winnipeg, Manitoba. The building is approximately 99 ft. in length, and Superintendent Davis has obtained a quotation of $3,000.00 to move the building to Portage la Prairie, from R. Litz & Sons, 277 McPhillips Street, Winnipeg.

This firm recommend that the building be cut in two halves, and temporary end walls be built at both the openings created by the cutting of the building in order to prevent the side walls from going out of shape in transit. They will also look after obtaining permits for moving the building, and will place it on the site selected by our officials at Portage la Prairie.

This firm can move the building immediately, and it is pointed out that this a most opportune time to move it, because the roads are firmly frozen and there is lighter traffic on the highway at this period of the year.

Our Building Supervisor, Mr. M. Krawchuk, who is attached to our Winnipeg office, considers that the firm mentioned above are in a position to handle the work in a competent manner. Regional Supervisor Davis recommends that they be employed as they promise to move the building at once. Funds for the moving are available in the current year's appropriation.
Therefore, I recommend for the Minister's approval, that we accept the tender of R. Litz & Sons to move the building mentioned above from its present location to the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, at a cost of $3,000.00.

Main Building

New single and three phase services are required to be installed. A blueprint is attached showing a proposed layout. No provision has been made for future additional load on the single phase service. Report - Portage la Prairie Residential School.

The following is the school staff:

Miss Rosenbush, Matron. Miss Bjur, Laundry Matron.
Miss Vosh, Auxiliary teacher, matron etc. Mrs. McDougal, senior teacher.
Miss Wescreschuk, junior Teacher.
Miss Quinn, Sewing Teacher. Miss Steele, Boys' Matron.
Miss McCann, Girls' Matron. Miss Hounsom, Kitchen Matron.
Mr. Roxborough, Farmer. Mr. Young, Engineer. Mr. Reeve,
Manual Training. Mr. Martin, night watchman.

Mrs. McDougal claims she has a Second class teaching certificate,
Manitoba. Miss Wescreschuk is teaching the junior room on a
permit. Mr. Young, Engineer, does not hold a certificate.

Mr. McLean, Principal, admitted that no fire-drills had been
carried out during the month of January, owing to the severe
frosty weather. He informed me that a drill would be carried
out during the afternoon of my visit. All extinguishers in
the building were examined. It was brought to the attention
of Mr. McLean that some extinguishers were not tagged, others
showed that the contents had not been changed since 1948, al-
though the majority would appear to have been refilled in
March 1949. I suggested a complete change of contents of all
extinguishers and that they be tagged showing the date of
change.

The electric wiring in the building should be checked. The
wiring is old fashioned and dangerous. The Principal stated
that he could not sleep at night owing to the worry of fire,
and I firmly believe there is a serious situation in the poor
condition of the wiring. The laundry switches should also be
checked, as there is a danger of children handling switches
with wet hands. A new washing machine has been installed in
the laundry. The pulleys were left open without protection.
I suggested that the pulleys be fenced with wire. The Principal
saw the danger immediately it was pointed out to him and I was
informed that a fence would be installed without delay.

The classrooms were crowded. Provision is being made for an
additional classroom. The junior teacher had a class of 52 -
57 on register - 5 boys away on other training in the after-
noon and 5 girls out in the morning. The teacher has 33 in
Grade 1 and 24 in Grade 2. This class is far too heavy for any
teacher to do full justice towards the children. There are 53
on the register in the senior room - 16 in Grade 4, 18 Grade 5,
6 Grade 6, 10 Grade 7, 3 Grade 8. There were 39 in the classroom
the day of my visit - February 15th. Grades 4 and 6 are in
school all day, and 5, 7 and 8 half-day.

Mr. McLean made request for twelve (12) double decker beds for
the boys' dormitory, complete with mattresses. The double
deckers would give more floor space in the dormitories and freer
access to the fire-escapes. I would strongly recommend that this
purchase be made.

Laundry was strung around the girls' lavatory, on heating pipes,
and in the closed-in verandahs. Mr. McLean asked if I could do
anything to expedite the delivery of a dryer that apparently has
been recommended. I found the Principal very co-operative and
interested in the work. Padlocks were found on the doors of the
dormitories. He advised that the doors were padlocked during the
day, but were left open at night. He did express dissatisfaction
at this arrangements. Several letters had been found in which it
was intimated that visits were arranged in the dormitories be-
tween the older boys and girls. The girls appeared to be the
aggressors. Mr. McLean stated that he would have to install
an alarm system, similar to the one in use at the File Hills
School.

Please refer to your letter of March 10th, file 583-5 (E1) relating to the above noted school.

(1) It was not my intention in the first place to have toilets put in the school. However, the Provincial Inspector thought they were necessary. As these children are close to the main building, there is no reason why they cannot use these facilities.

(2) Regarding the entrance to the furnace room being made through the fuel room, I am having Mr. Krawchuk adjust the plans to meet with this request.

(3) Mr. Krawchuk will be drawing a new plan of this building and will see that this change is made regarding the cloakroom.

(4) The furnaces that we got with this building are forced air heat, army type self-feed coal. Therefore, we will be using coal for heating purposes. I have had Mr. Krawchuk go over to Campbell Heating with a plan to get their advice on the best method of putting up these furnaces. I am of the opinion that we can heat the present classroom also, by running a pipe through where the buildings join; and on a very cold day the other furnace could be utilized.

(5) It was not my intention to change the roof in this building, as this would run into a couple of thousand dollars, and a new roof would only add to the appearance of the building. The present roof is a real good one, made of asphalt with rubberoid over the top. This roof will only need to be tarred and sanded, as no doubt it will be loosened from the moving. If a new roof was added, it would still need supports as the ceiling joists and the ceiling are in three pieces; therefore, it would still be necessary to have steel beams under them after the joists are taken down. The steel beams we are considering would be right up close to the ceiling and the beam underneath would be held by a bracket which attaches to the steel beam. In this way it will make a very neat job and the cost of the beams and installing would not be over approximately $500.00 for four beams.

(6) It is our intention to put transom type windows on the north side of the classroom, as we have plenty of room for these windows and the transom windows which are in the building now will be used.
The back end of this building has a slope roof, and it is our intention to use it for a recreation room. It has no floor at the present time, as in this part of the building the floor was a cement slab on the ground. On looking over the building yesterday, I feel that we should put a cement floor in this portion of the building as at the Airfield. This will mean building a wall underneath the pillars and insulating it and also across the building. This will give us about three feet more ceiling height, which is necessary for recreation, as the present ceilings, if a floor was put in, would not give enough height for playing basketball, etc.

I would very much like to get your opinion on the above and any other suggestions that you wish to make, and I will have Mr. Krawchuk draw another plan and submit it to you. When this is approved we will submit a list of the materials required or get contract prices on completing this building according to our plans and specifications. I feel the latter method would be better, as we would know where we were at, in place of undertaking the work on a day labor basis.

We could either complete this building by contracting the work and we supplying the material, or have a contractor supply the material and complete the work. You might let me know which method you feel is the best.

I am attaching herewith a rough sketch, showing the recreation room which will be practically three feet lower than the balance of the building, on a cement floor.

Sirs,— I beg to refer to the Department's letter No. 119469/1 dated May the 2nd, 1913, in reference to a suitable site for the new building for the Portage la Prairie Indian Boarding School.

In reply I beg to enclose a sketch map of what I consider the most suitable property of which I know for school purposes. It is known as the Cummings property and has to be sold this summer. Mr. T.A. Newman, Portage la Prairie, Man., is the sole executer. The portion South of the Canadian Northern Railway contains about 60 acres, is excellent soil, plenty of good water and on it a school could be built facing Crescent Lake almost opposite the Provincial Training School. The balance of this 210 acres is badly cut up by the different railways. Mr. Newman can sell it to the different farms which it is adjoining at $75 per acre. The property is a half-breed script and is, therefore, long and narrow.

The 60 acres South of the C.N.R. which would be most desirable for school purposes can be purchased at $85.00 per acre. It is one and a half miles from the Post Office which is regarded as the center of the city.

It is considered very suitable property on which to build a school for the following reasons: 1- The children could walk to Knox Presbyterian church and Sunday School. 2- It is on the road which leads to the Long Plain Reserve and parents coming to the city could easily see their children. 3- It is only about a mile and a half from Parish Lot No. 14 where many of the Sioux Indians have decided to reside in the future. 4- We would be nearer the Sioux Village than we are at present.
There is a small triangle § A. of three acres, owned by Mr. Lee who is married to a Miss Cummings' and as the buildings on it are of very little value, no doubt it could be bought at a very reasonable price. A better location for a building than this triangle could hardly be imagined.

If one was to purchase land anywhere within three miles of the center of the city it would cost from $60.00 to $75.00 per acre. The residential portion of the city must move along Crescent Road to the West. They will never go North on account of the Railways. The Provincial Farm cuts off the East, The Crescent Lake cuts off the South. In twenty years this Cummings property will be worth from $500.00 to $1000.00 per acre. It is three quarters of a mile from good residences on Crescent Road at present.

South and West of the city is the most suitable location for our work. North and East takes us away from it.

I shall try and get the prices of other property in the meantime.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

re Your Reference No. 119469/1.

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th Inst. and shall be glad to carry out your instructions at once. With reference to the purchase of the Cummings property, I beg to advise that I have obtained a Deed of the property from the executors of the estate of Margaret Cummings, and have registered it, and am proceeding with the necessary searches as to title. As soon as these are complete, I shall serve requisition upon the solicitor for the executors, and shall endeavour to get title in shape as early as possible. I imagine, however, that it will not be an easy matter.

Back in the early '80's this property was apparently subdivided and the Plan of Subdivision was never registered, but certain Deeds were issued to purchasers of Lots in accordance with the proposed Plan of Subdivision, and these Deeds are registered in the Land Titles Office here. It will be necessary, of course, to get rid of them in order to clear the paper title. At the present time they are an encumbrance on the property, and there is no way of defining just what portion of it they cover, because I fancy the proposed Plan of Subdivision (if it ever existed) has been lost years ago.

I think perhaps the easiest way out of the difficulty would be to obtain a Torrens title. You might let me know if I have your authority.
to obtain a Torrens title in case I find it impossible to get a good safe-holding title in any other way.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

F.G.T.

re sale from the executors of the Cummings Estate to the Indian Department.

I beg to advise you that I shall require the following, in order to make out a good title to the portion of Parish Lot 51 of the Parish of Portage la Prairie, which is now being purchased by the Dominion Government from the executors of Margaret Cummings deceased:

First: By registered Deed No. 7556, Thomas Logan and James B. Henderson, who were then the registered owners of the Parish Lot, conveyed to one Samuel Foote, a portion of the Parish Lot described as Lots Nos. 3 and 4, in Block B., according to a Plan thereof made by G.B. Bemister, D.L.S., and registered in the Registry Office for the County of Marquette West. There is no record in the Land Titles Office of any such Plan ever having been registered, and it is impossible, from any registered document which I can find, to locate the property. This Deed forms a cloud upon the title, which will have to be removed.

Secondly: By registered Instrument No. 10271, Messrs. Logan and Henderson conveyed to Frank Forsythe, a portion of Parish Lot No. 51, described as being Lots 5 and 6, in block B., according to the above Plan of Subdivision. My remarks with reference to the prior instrument will apply to this one.

Thirdly: The Patent from the Crown issued to Malcolm Cummings, and
in all the registered dealings which he had with the property, he spells his name with an "s" on the end of it, but the Probate of his Will under which the executors of Margaret Cummings make title, simply spells the name "Cunning" without the "s". We shall require a Declaration to clear up this small discrepancy. I presume there would be no difficulty in getting Mr. Thomas Cummings to make a Declaration which would be sufficient for this purpose.

Fourthly: Evidence of payment of the debts of Malcolm Cummings and of Margaret Cummings.

Fifthly: Payment of taxes.

It is just possible that in order to clear away the two Deeds mentioned in my first and second requisitions, it may be necessary to obtain a Torrens title to the property. I dare say it would be impossible now to locate the parties mentioned in them. If they can be located, and Quit Claim Deeds secured, there would be no necessity of getting a Torrens title.

I find on the General Register, two conveyances of land from Thomas Logan et al to Farquhar McLean and Thomas W. Boddy, registered as Nos. 83 and 4976, respectively. I have not yet searched these Deeds, but if the descriptions in them interfere with the title to Parish Lot 51, they would have to be cleared up.

Yours truly,

F.G.T.

### In Frost Field-Built Fence

Any number of Stays and Laterals can be used, producing many combinations other than illustrated. Posts can be placed at any distance from 16½ feet to 33 ft. apart, according to lay of ground. Our stiff stays and rigid locks permit the use of fewer posts.

Frost Maple Leaf Fence For inclosing Parks, Cemeteries and Lawns.

An ornamental fence in a class by itself and at a very low cost. Materials shipped in knocked down form for construction on either neatly trimmed or turned cedar posts, or iron posts with pipe top rail.

An almost endless variety of designs suiting every particular requirement can be built. Both Malleable and Stamped Steel Maple Leaves with galvanized coating are furnished and are securely attached to the Stays when so ordered, or can be supplied in bulk.

Frost Field-Built Fence

In strength and years of service this fence rivals a stone wall.

Materials for building this and the Maple Leaf fence illustrated on page 16, are shipped in knocked down form. The Horizontals are Genuine Frost Coiled Wire No. 9. Stays are made from No. 7 Gauge Hard Steel Wire (double the size and stiffness used in machine-made fence), straightened and cut to required lengths, with a loop or ring at the top, and are shipped in bunches. The Metal Locks for securely attaching these Heavy Steel Stays to the Coiled Laterals are cut and formed in automatic presses, then given a good coat of galvanizing. They are sold by the pound, averaging about 85.

Frost Field Built Fence has marked advantages over factory woven fence, and although more time is required to build it than to stretch machine made fencing, the appearance is so vastly better and will give so much longer service that all who continue to build and use this fence feel well rewarded for the extra work.

This better appearing and more substantial fence is used most extensively along roadsides at the fronts of property where especially neat and substantial fence is desired. The use of Maple Leaf Stays, as on page 16, converts it into an ornamental fence.

Other advantages are, that being put together on the posts, it fits uneven surfaces and is also suitable for stretching through woods and rough country. Any number of wires and stays can be used and spaced as desired.

The only special tools required for building it are the Block and Tackle with McCluskey Wire Grip, Hand Stretcher, and the Frost Locker for tightening the locks.

2. Location of fences.
3. Location and arrangement of trees, shrubs and flowering plants used for ornamental purposes.
4. Locations of drains and lawn service.

1. DRAINS.
Before preliminary grading is done a drain of three (3) inch farm tile is to be laid through ornamental ground at the most favorable location. Tile to be laid at a depth of three and one half (3½) feet. Drain to have a fall of two (2) feet to every one hundred (100) feet and to empty into a catch-basin or drain provided for the purpose.

2. LAWN SERVICE.
Provision to be made for a three quarter (¾) inch iron water pipe to be laid from most convenient source of supply to the centre of ornamental grounds. Pipe to be laid on the surface. To be supplied with suitable connections so that water may be cut off and lawn service pipe drained during winter. Upright at end and at suitable intervals in pipe to be supplied with suitable hose connections.

3. GRADING.
A topographical survey must be made of the grounds to be used for ornamental purposes and grading stakes set to show the amount of cut and fill necessary to bring surface of the grounds to permanent grade.

When brought to permanent grade, all lands for ornamental purposes must have a covering of at least ten (10) inches of good surface loam.

Before any grading is done sod on centre ornamental grounds to be plowed to a depth of six (6) inches and thoroughly pulverized with a disc harrow.

Where heavy outdoor fills are to be made, surface loam to a depth of ten (10) inches must first be removed and piled in such a position as to be used as a surface dressing in bringing lands up to the proper grade.

4. CULTIVATION.

After the necessary grading is done, surface of ornamental grounds should be given a thorough cultivation with a disc harrow and a drag harrow at intervals of a week until the surface is reduced to a finely pulverised condition.

As soon as conditions will permit in the spring before any planting is done the entire grounds to be given two thorough cultivations with a disc harrow or cultivator followed by a drag harrow.

5. PLANTING.

Trees and shrubs should be planted during the month of May or early part of June, before any foliage appears on deciduous trees or shrubs or just as the new growth is appearing on evergreen trees. Position of trees and shrubs must be carefully determined from plan and stakes set to mark such positions. All trees, shrubs and perennial plants used for ornamental purposes must be well grown, hardy and true to name. All stock for planting must be carefully lifted and delivered to the grounds in good condition.

As soon as stock is delivered at the grounds it shall be carefully unpacked, the roots thoroughly moistened, and the roots buried in soil until required for planting.

Holes for trees and shrubs should be dug to a depth of two (2) feet and large enough in circumference to take the roots without crowding.

In planting trees and shrubs two (2) inches of surface loam should be put in bottom of hole, root placed on this and five (5) inches of top loam placed on top of roots and carefully worked in with hand before other soil is filled in. In filling holes soil should be well compacted about roots.

6. SOWING SEED FOR LAWNS.

All land to be used for lawns must be well prepared with disc harrow and drag harrow. Before sowing seed, surface should be gone over with a garden rake and all coarse material raked up into a pile and removed.

Lawn seed must be sown before June fifteenth (15). The mixture must be first quality seed and composed of the following grasses, and clovers:

Kentucky Blue Grass; Canadian Blue Grass (25%) per cent; White Dutch Clover (50%) percent. Seed to be sown at the rate of two (2) pounds to every one thousand (1000) square feet of space. Seed must be sown broadcast and distributed evenly over the surface. After sowing, the surface of the soil should be gone over with a garden rake and the seed lightly raked into the surface. After raking, the surface is to be rolled with a garden roller and soil thoroughly composted about seed.

ROADS.

Roads to have a grade of not more than one (1) inch per foot from ditches at side to crown in centre. To be constructed of earth and finished with gravel. First course of gravel to be coarse gravel and four (4) inches in depth. Road to be sprinkled and rolled after earth grade is obtained and after both the first and second courses of gravel.

FALL ASSIZES 1917.

Portage la Prairie, November 9th, 1917.

TO HIS LORDSHIP, Justice MacDonald.

MAY IT PLEASE YOUR LORDSHIP:

We, the Grand Jury of the Central Judicial District of the Province of Manitoba for the Fall Assizes, beg leave to submit the following report:

We have had under our consideration ten indictments for all of which we returned true bills.

According to your instructions we have visited the various public buildings and report thereupon as follows:

The Court House.

We have been pleased to find that the Court House has been renovated throughout and fitted up with modern electric fittings and wiring; The Judge's Chamber and Petit Jury Room have had lavatories installed and telephones have been placed in the room of the Crown Prosecutor and also for the accommodation of the public.

We think it might improve the Court Room particularly with regard to acoustic qualities and ventilation if it were re-arranged so that the Judge might face south and the public enter and take their seats from two aisles, proceeding from south to North.

The Provincial Gaol.

We cannot speak too highly of the excellent effects the gaol produced upon us. The prisoners number at present 17, including one female, and their general appearance reflects the highest credit upon the gaol staff. The ventilation in the lower cell room is somewhat defective and we would recommend that the cells be moved into the part which is used at present as a chapel.
We notice in the engine room there is no railing to protect the workmen or the public from falling among the pumps and for their safety this should be done at once. The wooden fence partly surrounding the gaol yard is rather an eye sore. We recommend that it be removed and replaced with a fence rather more in keeping with the rest of the premises.

One commendable new feature is the root house in which are stored in safety against the frost enough vegetables raised by the prisoners themselves in the gaol garden to last the entire institution through the winter, in addition to which gardening there have been nearly three thousand hours labor of the prisoners spent in various public works.

The Hospital.

We were conducted through this institution by the Matron and find it excellent in every particular so far as we were able to judge. The patients number 24, 11 males and 13 females, and a staff altogether number 16, including two graduate nurses.

The Industrial School.

We spent a good deal of time in this institution which appears to be making excellent progress under Mr. McKinnon and staff, in turning out men fit to take their place worthily in the world. We examined the excellent stables, the school room, and all the various departments in the main building and found them all very satisfactory. We notice the blacksmith shop has been discontinued and recommend that this be re-opened and the blacksmith work of all public buildings sent to this shop to be done. The bedrooms for the staff here are very inadequate and bear no comparison with those in the Indian School. There is certainly some reason here for re-arrangement and no lack of room. The cattle are well cared for but we think it might be more in keeping with the excellence of the institution if they were improved and made more typical of the breed represented. We also think that a commercial teacher should be permanently employed.
and this course taught which should enable the boys to take a satisfactory place in business circles. We were pleasantly surprised to learn that the farm connected with the Home had raised over $20,000.00 worth of produce and are glad to call your Lordship's attention to this excellent record. The basement of the stable is filled with scores of tons of sugar beets, potatoes, and other garden produce.

The number of inmates is at present 64 and the staff numbers 22. The farm in connection is composed of about 300 acres.

The Indian School.

This is another institution which merits the highest praise. The Superintendent, Mr. Hendry, informed us that he is the only man living in the building and that all the manual labor is performed by the boys and girls under his charge who number altogether 76, that is 30 boys and 46 girls.

The children are apparently quite at home and quite happy, and their excellence of their technical work and the progress in education they have shown is a sufficient warrant for the continued support of this Branch of Indian Affairs.

We strongly recommend that the small farm in connection be increased by 28 acres adjoining, which we understand can now be purchased at a satisfactory price. This would be a purchase which would soon pay for itself as there is ample help to work it.

The Home for Incurables.

This is an excellent institution also and the devotion of the nurses and attendants under most trying circumstances is altogether admirable. It would be a libel to state that the world was getting worse when such institutions are provided and maintained by public charity to care for feeble minded and infirm persons. The buildings are scrupulously clean and well cared for and in Mr. O'Brien, the Superintendent, we feel that
the Government has a very efficient and capable officer.

The Old People's Home.

What has been said of the Home for Incurables is no less true of the Old People's Home. It was a pleasure to inspect this institution and the cleanly, cheerful and even happy old people should give a lesson in contentment to any observant visitor. The patients' both Homes number 335, and the staff 36. The farm in connection is composed of about 300 acres, all of which is respectfully submitted.

Stephen Benson.
Foreman.

Dear Sir:

We beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant and since its receipt have had a couple of interviews with Mr. Stacey.

Prior to the receipt of your last letter, Mr. Stacey had been in and had made an offer to retain three and a half (3½) acres in the immediate vicinity of the buildings and it would of course include the buildings, and take $13,000.00 for the balance. This would work out a little more than $116.00 per acre for the land exclusive of buildings.

After receipt of your letter of the 8th instant we saw Mr. Hendry, the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Boarding School and he expressed a very strong desire to have the buildings; he did not say that he did not want the land without the buildings but that he would a great deal rather pay $130. per acre for the whole thing than pay $13,000. and allow Mr. Stacey to retain the buildings and the acreage mentioned above, along with them. The writer then saw Mr. Stacey again and had a long interview with him. He wants to sell the place but at the same time he is just as anxious to retain the buildings. He would not, however, consider the $115.00 an acre for the whole thing. When he left the office he seemed inclined to
allow us to submit an offer of $120.00 an acre and you take everything. We told him if he would do that we would recommend its acceptance but that we of course, could go no further than that and that we would be very doubtful if you would take it at that price. He said he would think the matter over until the next day and see us again. When he came back he told us that he had made up his mind that he would not vary his original proposition, that is:

1. To take $130.00 per acre and sell the whole thing outright.

2. To take $13,000.00 and retain the buildings and 3½ acres of land along with them.

We told him that we had no idea that you would accept either proposition but that we would submit them for your consideration.

We have not seen Mr. Hendry since our last interview with Mr. Stacey. I am inclined to think that if he had offered him $115.00 an acre for the property before Mr. Hendry got his option of $130.00, Stacey would have accepted it, but he knows of course, that you want the property and that his is practically the only property you could get which would answer your purposes and in consequence is hard to deal with.

He asked me to request that if you did not want to accept the option which you already have that you should surrender to him and let him go on with his Fall work. MEMORANDUM

Hon. Mr. Meighen -

The purchase of the Stacey property for the Portage la Prairie school has been successfully carried out. Mr. Taylor, who looked after the purchase for us, expects a commission on the transaction as well as his fee for searching the title. He writes under date of November 14th, as follows:

"Would you please be good enough to advise me what commission your Department allow on a purchase of this kind? The usual commission here is 5% and if satisfactory I will render you a bill on that basis."

I find that when the original site for the school was purchased at Portage la Prairie we allowed Mr. Taylor 5% as well as his fee for searching the title. In the present instance Mr. Hendry, principal of the school, had obtained an option on Mr. Stacey's property at $120.00 an acre. Mr. Taylor no doubt took some trouble to get Mr. Stacey to reduce his price, but without avail, and we ended in paying $120.00.

I would be glad if you would direct me what to pay Mr. Taylor by way of commission. The full amount at 5% would be $759.25.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir,

As no doubt you may have seen in my last report on the Fortage Le Prairie Indian Boarding School, (April 29, No. 2924) a recommendation that the land adjoining the school land, about 100 acres be bought for the use of the school.

I have heard recently that the land wanted, has been bought by the Department, and if nothing interferes, I would like to know if such is the case. If the land has been bought, there are certain changes necessary to the house that is on the farm, so that it may be used as a residence for the Principal.

The last time I visited the school, Mrs Hendry told me that the strain of the work, living in the school, was such on her that they were now seriously thinking of leaving the work, and moving to British Columbia, where they have a small fruit farm in one of the valleys. During the conversation I suggested that if the land above mentioned was bought, they could have the house on the farm fixed up and move over there to live, and put in a male assistant at the school. This move would be agreeable to Mr. and Mrs. Hendry, and would also solve another problem of the school, the want of a Junior class-room. The partition between the parlour and dining room, now used by them could be taken out at little expense, and the room thus made, about 16 X 32 would make a fine class-room. There is plenty of room for a male assistant without these two rooms, and the cost of fitting up the house on the farm, would be in the vicinity of $1000.

Mr. Hendry makes a model for this kind of Indian work, and I would not like to see him leave the service.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Duncan G. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. Gen. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Mrs. Clark,

Your letter of the 3rd to hand re efforts of the Non-concurring to secure control of the Portage la Prairie School.

The first hint I got on the matter was from Mr. Inspector Jno. R. Bunn of Winnipeg. I was in his office about a month ago and learned that Mrs. Judge Robinson had been consulting with Mr. Bunn as to which school they should ask for and he advised her strongly to center on Portage as it was by far the best school. Mr. Bunn is an Anglican but his sympathies are EVERLASTINGLY Presbyterian. Somehow or other he thought me an Anti and opened up by telling me that he had a visit from my friend Mrs. Judge Robinson but later when he found that I was United all talk on the matter ended.

Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree openly told me that the Presbyterians told him that they were putting in a claim for Portage school, and that Mr. Paterson, Manitoba organizer, was going to take the matter up with Commissioner Graham of Regina. They also said that if they did not get the School they would not take the Sioux Village.

No matter what is done in Regina every detail will have to go to Ottawa and come before the Deputy Minister, D.C. Scott, and the question of where are their children to fill the school will be the deciding factor. Only six children from the Sioux village are in school and there are 98 on the roll and five of these are children of United people, as they signed up for the United Church. One only is Presbyterian, and they have no territory that could be used to help the school. Their case looks absolutely ridiculous.

Mr. Macpherson, M.P. is United, was former Methodist but I do not know him very well. I fancy that when the Department look into the case they would see the impossibility. If it went we would build aday school at Long Plain reserve and all the recruiting ground would be cut off.

Ottawa should be conversant with the situation so as to be ready should it come up.

You are perfectly right about Commissioner Graham. I think that all the workers would welcome a return to the old system when we had Inspectors and dealt with the Department at Ottawa more direct and to have the Regina office abolished. It was established over the head of the War Cry Greater Production Movement and I am sure the work would be carried on better if we were more closely in touch with Ottawa.

I am

Very truly yours,

(sgd.) W.A. Hendry

Power lines, in arranging with private owners, as a rule prefer to do so on a basis of so much per pole or tower, but it is more usually the custom of the Department to demand a payment at a price per acre. It must be remembered in making your valuation that the privilege requested constitutes a permanent easement and has therefore considerable effect on the market value of the whole property. You're requested to return the blueprint with your report. Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am writing to you for instruction in the procedure to be adopted in dealing with a case of a serious nature.

Mary Atkinson (the daughter of Bitt Atkinson #252 of Roseau Indian Reserve) was allowed home for the holidays on the first of July this year in the care of her parents. I visited the reserve on the 30th day of August and was informed by the Farm Instructor (Mr. J.C. Scott) that the parents of Mary had married her to an Indian of Warroad in U.S.A.

The marriage is, I understand, a so-called Indian marriage. I have checked up the age of this child and find that the father received the first payment for Mary in the treaty payments in nineteen twenty four 1924 a notation in the book stating "Girl born". Mary was enrolled in the Portage-la-Prairie school on the 16th of August and the age given was 7 years. This was in the year 1931.

I have discussed this with the local Agent Mr. Waite, and with the Mounted Police. It is my desire to lay information against the father Bitt Atkinson and the Indian Edward Blackbird of Warroad, U.S.A. The father was well aware that Mary was under age.

The case is complicated by the fact that Blackbird is a United States Indian. This difficulty is by no means insurmountable. I shall be glad if you would take up this serious case with the Headquarters of the Mounted Police in Ottawa and ask them to forward instructions to the Sergeant in charge at Portage-la-Prairie.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones.

Re: - Mary Atkinson -

Dear Mr. Jones:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 5th instant, in which you ask that action be taken against an American Indian named Blackburde and the father of the above noted girl - both of whom, it is alleged, are guilty of a criminal offence.

Your letter of September 20, 1938, was forwarded to the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police with a covering letter, in which the Commissioner was asked to make a full investigation of this particular case. The investigating officer in a report to his Superior Officer, which has now reached the Department, states:

"As this alleged marriage ceremony took place in the United States, it is possible that this type of marriage may be legal with American Indians. Should this be the case, then there is very little that can be done about the matter. Should, however, this type of marriage be illegal, then it is evident that Blackburde is guilty of an offence and that the father of the girl, Pitt Atkinson, is also guilty of contributing to juvenile delinquency. I would respectfully request that this matter be referred to the Indian Department with a view to having a further investigation made by the American authorities."

In view of the fact that this alleged offence took place -

Reverend Joseph Jones,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.
took place in the United States, it is somewhat difficult to know just what action should be taken by the officials here in an attempt to have the guilty parties punished. I have this morning discussed this matter very fully with the officials of this Branch, and it is our opinion that this girl or her mother, or both, should be encouraged to lay a charge against Blackburde before the proper American authorities. If she can be persuaded to do this, I feel confident action would be taken immediately by the American officials to have the matter brought before a court of competent jurisdiction. If however the girl refuses to do this, it will be somewhat difficult for us to take the matter up effectively at Washington, in the absence of any request from the girl that proceedings should be instituted.

I shall be glad to hear from you again with respect to this matter.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, February 1, 1939.

Re - Mary Atkinson -

Dear Mr. Jones:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 27th ultimo, in which you suggest that, in view of all the circumstances, you as guardian of the above named pupil should lay the information and proceed with the case against Edward Blackburde and Ritt Atkinson.

I am convinced that there will be no objection whatever on the part of the Department to this course of action, and it is my opinion that the case should be proceeded with at once.

I was somewhat surprised and disturbed at your reference to Laura Onesides of the Swan Lake reserve. It has never been the policy of the Department so far as I am aware to deny illegitimate children admission to residential schools simply because the putative father was supposed to be an American citizen. If such a ruling was given by the Department, I should like to have the exact date of the letter and any other information you may care to send forward.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I have been discussing the case re Mary Atkinson with Mr. Webster our Local magistrate.

Dear Mr. Jones:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the first instant and to thank you for the information contained therein. It would appear from the records that the above noted pupil was enrolled at the Portage Residential School and that later an application was sent forward to the Department asking for the approval of her admission.

The admission of this girl was not approved for the simple reason that the agent intimated that she was the child of an American Indian, that her father had been put off the Lake reserve and that, in view of the number of our own Indians now eligible for admission, the claim of this girl for admission should not be considered. It would appear that the Indian agent had the impression that because this girl was the child of an American Indian she was somehow or other ineligible for admission. Just how he received this impression I am not in a position to state.

In view of the fact that this girl is now 11 years old and has been attending the day school regularly and has reached an age when she can be useful to her mother, I am not at all sure that she will be unwilling to enroll at the residential school now, nor am I sure that it would be advisable to wait her out this comparatively late date. This is a matter however that can be discussed by you and the Indian agent. Any joint recommendation you may care to make will be carefully and sympathetically considered by the Department.

Re - Laura Onesides

Dear Sir:

A few weeks ago the Reverend Joseph Jones in a letter to the Department intimated that children of American Indians who may have established residence on Indian reserves in Canada from time to time are ineligible for enrolment at our residential schools. In view of this fact he was of the opinion that legal proceedings should be instituted against an American Indian who had lived for a time with a young Indian girl, formerly a pupil at the Portage School, but who later sent this girl back to her parents on the Rosseau reserve. In an attempt to substantiate his contention, the Principal of the Portage la Prairie School referred to the case of Laura Onesides of the Swan Lake reserve. In my reply to the Principal I stated:

"I was somewhat surprised and disturbed at your reference to Laura Onesides of the Swan Lake reserve. It has never been the policy of the Department so far as I am aware to deny illegitimate children admission to residential schools simply because the putative father was supposed to be an American citizen. If such a ruling was given by the Department, I should like to have the exact date of the letter and any other information you may care to send forward."

The Principal has now sent forward copies of two letters, dated December 6, 1935, and September 6, 1938, received by him from you, in one of which you state that "the application of this girl to the Portage la Prairie School has not been approved by the Department." In your letter dated September 6, 1938, you state: "In reply I have to advise that as this girl is non-treaty, regulations do not permit her entering a residential school as a grant-earning pupil."

The records indicate that this girl was refused admission and that this refusal was based on a recommendation contained in a letter received by the Department from you, dated November 27, 1935. In this letter you state:

"This girl - Laura Onesides - is the daughter of an American National who was removed from the Swan Lake reserve some years ago. I do not recommend the admittance of this girl as the school can be readily filled by children of treaty Indians. The mother is paid under ticket 116."

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.
The Acting Superintendent of Indian Education in his reply dated December 3, 1935, stated in part:

"In view of the information given in your letter, the Department is not prepared to approve the admission of this girl, and you should so inform the Principal."

The Department has of course the right to admit or refuse admission to pupils applying for enrolment at residential schools at any time. In reaching decisions however we are usually guided by the recommendations of our Indian agents. This particular pupil - Laura Onesides - was refused admission to the Portage School on your recommendation and not because she was the child of an American Indian and certainly not because she was non-treaty. This is the point I want to emphasize.

You are probably aware that there is a statutory provision in the United States Immigration Act, whereby Canadian Indians are admitted to the United States, despite immigration and quota laws that may exist from time to time. A great many Canadian Indians take advantage of this opportunity in an attempt to secure employment. Canadian Indians seeking entry to the United States have never, so far as I am aware, been refused admission. In actual practice the Canadian Government follows the same procedure although we have no statutory provision granting American Indians free right of entry to this country. No American Indian, so far as I am aware, has ever been refused admission, although an American Indian with a criminal record or suffering from a contagious disease would no doubt be refused admission to this country.

You can readily grasp therefore the significance of this ruling. If we deny the children of American Indians access to our educational institutions, it would be only rational to suppose that the Americans would deny educational opportunities to Canadian Indians residing in the United States.

It is fortunate in this case that there is an Indian day school on the Swan Lake reserve and that this girl has been in attendance at this school. If this had not been the case she would almost certainly have grown up illiterate. The returns indicate that she has been attending this school regularly and is now 12 years of age. It is just possible, in view of her age and her usefulness to her mother, that she may not be anxious to enroll at the residential school. This is a case that should be discussed by you with the Principal of the Portage School and all misunderstandings relating thereto cleared.
cleared up. We simply cannot allow the impression to get abroad that we are denying American Indians educational opportunities in this country.

You might in your reply explain exactly what you mean by the term "non-treaty". More than half the Indians of Canada are non-treaty in the sense that they receive no treaty payment. Do you mean by non-treaty a white citizen who may be referred to as a halfbreed? Such an individual of course is a white citizen and his children are by that very fact ineligible for enrolment at one of our schools.

I am writing to the Principal and intimating to him that you will discuss this case with him in due course.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

H. A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, February 28, 1939.

Dear Mr. Jones:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 24th instant and also letter received by you from Superintendent E.C.P. Salt, Royal Canadian Mounted Police, attached thereto.

I can see no valid objection whatever to your going to Warrad in an attempt to secure a conviction against Edward Blackburde.

I can readily appreciate the difficulty the police would experience in securing evidence to prove that an offence had been committed in Canada. I think I reminded you in one of my preceding letters that I had a great deal of experience in handling such cases over a period of four or five years in the province of Manitoba. My experience was that it was almost impossible to secure a conviction in these cases. I heartily agree with you, however, that the difficulties of the case should not deter you from taking action. I regret that there does not appear to be closer cooperation in such matters between the Department here and the Department of Indian Affairs in the United States. There is nothing on file here to indicate that such cases have been referred at any time to the United States authorities.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,

On this date I received a telephone message from the Rev. Jones at Portage La Prairie asking what steps had been taken in the matter. He was informed as to what had been done and he stated that if the boy did not arrive at the School he would call again.

---

**5-9-39**

On this date Capt. Eaton of this Detachment had to make a Patrol to Dominion City to attend to some other Police duties so he was instructed to call at the FUKKINA home and ascertain if the boy had been sent to School. When JEW. EATON arrived at FUKKINA's he found FUKKINA and the boy just leaving for Portage La Prairie. While he stayed there they left for Portage. No further information has been received from the Rev. JONES so the boy will have arrived at the School. Rev. JONES was going to call on the 6th or 7th Sept., if the boy did not arrive, this boy being being returned to the School this File will now be concluded. Extra copy attached for Department concerned.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant with reference to the Portage la Prairie Indian residential school.

Please advise the Principal that in view of the short distance that they live from the Swan Lake day school it is considered that Laura Oneside, Mabel Oneside, Daniel Walker and Alex Contois should attend that school rather than the Portage la Prairie residential school. Mr. Jones should, therefore, arrange to have these children returned to their parents immediately.

Provided they are physically fit the Department is prepared to favourably consider the admission to the Portage la Prairie school of the 2 children at Sioux Village and Mary Soldier from Swan Lake.

I have reviewed our file and find that the 3 Swain children and the 2 McKinney children were admitted to the Portage la Prairie school on the basis of the former regulation regarding the admission of halfbreeds. As they have been in the school for some time I hesitate to disrupt their class room work by insisting on their immediate discharge. You might, however, advise Mr. Jones that these children should be discharged at the end of June, 1940, and they can be replaced by others.

The Swain and McKinney children should attend the Swan Lake day school during the academic year 1940-41.

Yours truly,

Mr. A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. White,

I understand that the children of Donald Francis of Long Plain are not receiving proper care owing to the serious illness of the father. It has been suggested that I find a place for these three children in the school. I am willing to take them in after I have returned the children to Swan Lake as instructed by the Department.

In view of the Department's decision re the four children from Swan Lake, I would like some assurance that the Francis children will be admitted as grant earning pupils.

I am well aware that the present authority is for 95 grant earning pupils and although I think that a request for an increase to a pupilage of 100 is quite reasonable, I am not using the admission of these three as a leverage to obtain that increase.

I am merely asking that after we have cleaned them up, re-clothed them and started them out in good sound health, I shall not receive instruction to return them home without ever receiving any grant for them.

I am going over the list of our pupilage with a view of asking for the discharge of those who are not capable of making further progress and thus make a place for others who ought to be in school.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

Sir:

I would be pleased to have the Department's advise on this matter.

Dear Mr Waite,

I have a report from Doctor Campbell of Dynevor Hospital stating that John Swain and Clifford Johnnie are making good progress and will probably be discharged in the course of a few months. I think it will be disastrous for John to send him home when he comes out of hospital, however it is out of my hands now that the Department have ruled that he must be discharged.

In Clifford Johnnies case may I point out that the report from the Doctor states "The Tuberculosis in his chest is not serious and a few months stay will probably be sufficient." This boy's father, Ben Johnnie, is a bad tubercular case and therefore it would not be advisable to return the boy home upon discharge from hospital. If Clifford is an arrested case I do not see why he could not be returned to school.

In reference to Tony Cameron 192. If the parents will give consent and the Department will approve I would like to see Tony go on to high school, he is above the average in ability and would make good use of his advanced training.

John Smith 193. I will ask for his discharge in the September quarter. The Senior pupils who are to be discharged should remain in school to help with the work, the farm work is just at its busiest time, row crop work, haying and harvest. I think it is only right that these pupils who have received all the benefits of school life should help the younger pupils in this way.

Re-Clifford Johnnie's Case. The discharge form was filled out here to indicate what disposition had been made of this boy. This should not have been done on the discharge form but on the return sheet. It is evidently our mistake here and I am sure the Department will allow the boy to be returned to school upon the Doctor's recommendation.

Yours sincerely

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo enclosing application for the admission of Georgealine Tanner to the Portage la Prairie Residential School. Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant with reference to funds for transportation of pupils going home on holidays from the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

1. With reference to the above I have to report that in the A.M. of the above date, a phone call was received from Mr. G.H. HENZIE, Principal at the Indian Residential School, to the effect that two boys had failed to return to the school after going out the previous evening.

2. In accordance with instructions received from the N.C.O. I/c, this detachment, the writer, accompanied by Cst. Henzie, patrolled to the school and obtained the following description of the missing boys:

Wallace JOHNNIE, age 15 yrs. 5'8" tall, well built, walks with slouch. Wearing brown windbreaker with zipper fastener, and black boots.

Frank EDWARDS, age 15 yrs. 5'2" tall, well built, erect carriage, speaks very good English and acts as spokesman for both. Wearing blue brushed wool sweater, black cap, and black boots.

3. The writer interviewed several of the boys at the school in an effort to determine the intentions of the runaways or their probable whereabouts. All that could be learned was that they had intended to board a freight train and look for work in a different part of the province. They apparently had no definite plans other than running away from school.

4. Further inquiries were made at the Sioux Village in this city, where it was found that one Mike PASOHI had been with JOHNNIE and EDWARDS the previous evening, and had left them after they boarded a freight train, preparing to leave for Winnipeg. Nothing further could be learned with regard to their proposed destination, and further inquiries made locally met with no result.

5. Both these boys are from the Roseau Indian Reserve near Letellier, Man., and it appears likely that they will return to their homes there, especially as they were not prepared, in the way of clothing, for the present cold weather. It is therefore respectfully requested that inquiries be made by Emerson Detachment at the Roseau Reserve and this detachment advised if the boys are located.

6. Extra copy of report for the information of the N.C.O. I/c, Emerson Detachment.

Reverend Sir:

Within the last two weeks the Department has received three reports from the R.C.M.P. with reference to the action they have taken in endeavouring to locate Wallace Johnnie and Frank Edwards, truant pupils of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. The expenses of the R.C.M.P. in this connection will amount to upwards of $35.00 which amount will have to be paid by the Department.

In this connection I should appreciate your advising what action you took to have these pupils returned without cost to the Department. In this regard I would refer you to official letter of May 8, 1941, copy of which is attached. Was a determined effort made by yourself or any other Departmental official to have these children returned without consulting the police? Under present conditions the R.C.M.P. have plenty of other more important matters to look after.

It also appears from the report of the police that the fact of the pupils truancy was broadcast over Station VIGT, Winnipeg. Our residential school system has been subject to considerable criticism and it is difficult for us to convince ourselves that broadcasting truancy of Indian pupils from an Indian residential school will tend to popularize Indian residential schools either with Indians or white people.

Yours truly,

Rev. Joseph Jones,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 20th I beg to submit the following:

Wallace Johnnie and Frank Edwards left the school with the intention of working on some farms West of Portage. That is what they told the boys, fifteen minutes after they left I discovered their absence, I immediately phoned a description of them to the local Detachment of the R.C.M.P. before proceeding to search for them in my own car. The Police are patrolling the highways nightly and it seems to me they are the logical people to inform. I did not ask them to broadcast the truancy of the boys and I did not know they had done so until you informed me by your letter.

The boys turned up on their own Reserve at Roseau. I asked if the police could secure them and return them to the school.

I have been in charge here over six years and before that at Ahousaht B.C. at both these schools truancy has been very rare, if you will look up the records you will find that in these more than twelve years this is the first item of expense for truancy you have been asked to pay, I shall be pleased to pay the account myself and thus keep the slate clean.

In reference to the popularity of the School may I point out that I do not have to ask for pupils, they are brought here by the parents and I have always had a waiting list. At present I have seven over the number of grant earning pupils, similar conditions prevailed at Ahousaht. I have no desire to have the rare cases of truancy broadcast, it was done without my knowledge or consent.

These are very restless times, the senior boys and girls sense the unrest and want to get into the centres where the soldiers are stationed, they hear stories of the "thrilling" times that the girls who have graduated from our schools are having at the army centres. The boys hear stories from the Indian boys who are in the army and want to have the same kind of freedom from restraint.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones
Winnipeg. Emerson.

Ottawa, August 31, 1942.

Re: Lena (Patsy) Daniels.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 27th instant and also copies of correspondence sent forward therewith, relating to the enrolment of the above-named pupil at the Portage la Prairie Residential School.

It is scarcely necessary to state that as a general policy everything humanly possible should be done to prevent the transfer of Indian pupils from one denominational school to another. These transfers not only interrupt the pupils' studies but must in the nature of things prove to be a source of confusion and perplexity to the pupils who are transferred from time to time.

The records here indicate that Lena Daniels was enrolled at the Portage la Prairie School on March 3, 1937. The application form was signed by the father, George Daniels, who described himself as a Protestant (United Church). I should like to know when George Daniels became a Roman Catholic. It would appear that this man has been remarried in recent years. Was the ceremony performed by a Catholic Priest or by a Minister of the Protestant Church? Is he a regular attendant at a Catholic church at the present time? The application form for admission to a residential school reads:

"I hereby make application for admission of the under-mentioned child into the _______ residential school; to remain there under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper."

Indian parents should be told that it is not their privilege to transfer their children from one residential school to another simply because they have become temporarily dissatisfied with the principal of a particular school.

It is noted that the letter signed by George Daniels was sent forward to you by the Reverend Father Lemire, Principal of the Sandy Bay Residential School. I am personally of the opinion that it would be much better for all parties concerned if the enrolment and discharge of pupils at our residential schools were left to our Indian agents and the principals of the schools concerned. I am anxious that you should have a personal interview with George Daniels and secure from him, to the greatest extent possible, the information requested in this letter. The officials here find it difficult to convince themselves, in view of this

Mr. J. Waite,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

p.t.o.
man's attitude to this child in the past, that he has become a Catholic in anything other than a very nominal sense. When the information requested reaches the Department, the matter will be again carefully reviewed.

I am returning herewith the letter received by you from the Reverend Joseph Jones, Principal of the Portage la Prairie Residential school.

Yours truly,

Encl.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

The Hon. T. A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

I have been requested by several good farmers of the Portage District to ask you if it would be possible to grant leave of absence from school of the older children in the Industrial (Indian) School at Portage la Prairie. I am informed that many of these children, both boys and girls, are fairly mature and able to perform heavy duty on the farm. It appears that they cannot leave school unless they obtain a Government permit. Now it may be that the permit would have to come through the United Church which institution I believe has charge of the administration of this particular Indian School. You will know the proper procedure in such cases. I think myself the move would be very popular and I think these children would be tickled to death to help the farmers produce food during these wartimes. The order would be better if it allowed these boys and girls to participate in the seeding operations but if that is impossible the move should come as soon as it can be arranged.

Thanking you for your consideration and anticipating an early reply, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Harry Leader, M.P.,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Ottawa, February 26, 1943.

Dear Mr. Leader:

I have received your letter of February 26, in which you discuss the desirability of having a number of the senior pupils of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School released for farm work.

You may be interested to learn that a number of somewhat similar requests reached the Department last year. The matter was fully discussed with the churches at that time, particularly the United Church officials. The churches point out that they are experiencing the utmost difficulty in securing the farm help necessary for the operation of their school farms. They state, also, that the number of teen-age pupils enrolled at residential schools has shown a drastic reduction since the outbreak of the war; and this claim is supported by our records. In addition to this, the churches depend upon the receipt of per capita grants for the support and operation of their schools. Under existing regulations, when a pupil is released for farm work or for any other cause, payment of the per capita grant ceases.

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, a list of the pupils enrolled at the Portage la Prairie School who have reached the age of 18 years or over. You will note that there are few boys whose services would be of much value on a farm during the seeding season. Only one boy has reached the age of 18. If you feel, however, that the matter is sufficiently urgent, I shall be glad to have the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch discuss it with the representatives of the Home Mission Board of the United Church.

Yours sincerely,

Harry Leader, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.
